reviewText:
The obsession with Ninjas in popular culture began in the '80s when Hollywood produced a few Ninja movies which happened to make a lot of money. As sure as the Sun rises in the East, the smell of profits ensured that a few Ninja movies soon became a plethora and eventually a torrent. Everything martial arts related became popular. Movies by Jean-Claude Van Damme, Steven Seagal and the legendary Chuck Norris inundated the public. Sure, some of them were not bad, but just as a cow produces milk, it also produces manure. Lots of it.

Fortunately for fans, the passage of time hasn't blunted the enthusiasm of Van Damme and Seagal who are still prolific today, producing straight-to-DVD movies with the regularity and consistency of a dyspeptic sybarite with irritable bowel syndrome. As for Seagal[lebeauleblog.com], he is now better known for spending more time at the buffet table than at the training dojo, preparing for his next blockbuster by subsisting on a stringent diet of Buffalo Wings. It is rumoured on the IMDB website that Seagal turned down a part in The Expendables 3 because he wanted to star alongside Harrison Ford in the new Star Wars film as Jabba the Hutt's son.

For anyone who doesn't know, The Expendables is the prestigious action movie franchise where famous action movie stars compete to see who can be more incomprehensible. So far, Slyvester Stallone and Jason Statham are tied for the top spot. In early editions of the DVD (since recalled), a production error dubbed over the actors with these guys and nobody noticed the difference.

Anyway, history buffs might be interested to know that not only is Ninjutsu a venerable art with a long and proud history in Japan, it was practised as far away as the Caribbean, brought there by Ninja-Pirates migrating across the Pacific Ocean. Joining a Ninja clan is simplicity in itself as traditional Ninja membership policies are extremely non-discriminatory as seen in the remarkable documentary Beverly Hills Ninja. In fact, being human is not even a necessary pre-requisite for being a Ninja. Robots, mutants, pet turtles and cheerleaders are all eligible.

As the epitome of martial arts, anyone would think that becoming a Ninja would take strict discipline and many years of intense training, but nothing is further from the truth. Simply yelling Ninja Power Now!" while gesticulating idiotically in the manner of an epileptic mime is all it takes.

In Mark of the Ninja
date: the developers Klei draws on the vast legacy of Ninja mythology to deliver an intriguing 2-D stealth platformer that does justice to the Ninja genre. Your job is to guide Mark
recommended: a slightly fruity human Luddite Ninja
hoursPlayed: on his epic quest to defeat the bad guys by destroying all their lamps. The darkness will create serious Workplace Health and Safety issues and cause severe embarrassment at the next WHS inspection. That'll teach em.\n\nLevels are well designed usually with multiple paths to objectives. Just like in Deus Ex: Human Revolution covert and overt playstyles are supported. The stealth action is incredibly well integrated into the gameplay
voteText: with the option for non-lethal pacifist vegans to ghost through every level without killing a single thing. It's even possible to hide in a box Metal Gear style. Sadly
helpfulPercent: the time-honoured stealth tactic of putting a lampshade on your head and pretending to be a lamp isn't implemented.\n\nWith an engaging narrative
votesHelpful: responsive controls and a beautiful art style that is uniquely Klei
votesTotal: this is the best and only stealth platformer I've ever played."

reviewText:
Mark of the Ninja  is a 2D plattforming stealth game where you take on the role as  The Marked one, an agile and badass ninja set out to avenge and save his clan.
The game got a very uniqe and beautiful art stile, really great and responsive controlles, slick animations that never gets old, a suprisingly good story with a couple of interesting characters. Every level can be can be completed in several different ways which opens up alot of freedom in how you like to play it and a some different unlockable equipment and skills to help your playstile. How you chooses to play does however not affect the story, even though it got two endings, only your score.
It got quite alot of replayability with a very interesting score system that rewards you for your playstile, several of different challenges on every level and a new game plus that lets you replay the campaign being harder, but with all of your unlocks.
It plays well both with a controller and mouse and keybord.
And i can't really think of anything to complain about, nothing big atleast.
So if you're a fan of  stealth games then i definitely recommend you'll check out this game out, becuse i sure enjoyed it alot.

reviewText: If you want to feel like a ninja, this is the game. With an arsenal of fancy moves, gadgets, and murder methods, this is 2D stealth at its finest and stands as one of my favourite sneak-em-ups, 2D or not. Extremely polished and well put together, it looks and controls great, and it's just so much fun to creep around and terrorize your enemies, with stealth that's similarly satisfying as the Arkham games. You're powerful and lethal in the shadows but vulnerable when seen, and as the game progresses you'll have to come up with fancier and fancier tactics to overcome the escalating security and new varieties of enemy immune to this thing or that. Succeed and you feel like the ultimate badass, fail and you're a fumbling idiot.  It's all wrapped up in an excellently presented package with an enjoyable, if simple story to work through.\n\nIt's a little on the easy side, but there is a new game+ mode in which all gunshots are fatal and your vision is more limited, etc. Definitely more challenging, but still beatable. There is a quicksave option that doesn't penalize you for using it, which can suck the difficulty out of things a little if you're prone to save-scumming.  Because things can go so very wrong so very quickly, it's a welcome addition but it does make things a little less tense.

General info
~Genre: Platform, stealth
~Number of players: 1
~Completion time: 6-15 hours
~Downloadable content: available

Strong points
+Stealth at its best (Hide into shadows, avoid flashes of thunders, hide bodies, confuse watchdogs, play mind tricks with the guards, disable electric devices, etc.)

+Voice acting and music (just hear that sword slashing your enemies' flesh)

+Challenging (as you progress enemies become more potent)

+Useful ninja tools (including smoke bombs and flesh eating bugs)

+An indie game equal to AAA titles

+Price

Weakness
-Downloadable content of minor value

My rating5/5
The Ninja Scroll of video games. It wouldn't be an overstatement to number it among the top 5 stealth games of all time.

reviewText: A lot of people throw the term ninja" around the internet like they're trying to repaper the walls with it. People claim to be "ninjas" after watching a dozen or so episodes of the wrong cartoon
date: after they buy an unsharpened aluminum samurai sword at a flea market
recommended: or just whenever they're trying to impress people anonymously.\nSo when I point out that I write this review "from the standpoint of a ninja
hoursPlayed:
I'm aware of how half-witted and watered down the term is. But a ninja is nothing if not determined to overcome tough odds, so here goes; time to ♥♥♥♥ up this rope.

Mark of the Ninja is possibly the best ninja-themed stealth game I've ever played, and I've played nearly all of them.
The first major note to its credit is, Mark of the Ninja favors gameplay over realism or historical accuracy. The player can always tell how visible they are based on the tone of the character's graphic. Enemies can see things which are in the light and can't see things which are in the dark. Walking footsteps are silent, and running footsteps make noise in an area around the character; the distance they can be heard from is indicated with a graphic on screen.
Open combat is virtually nonexistant and, most importantly, avoidable. The code of the Hisomu family demands that their sword be used only on an unaware enemy, and as such every patrol of guards can be outwitted and avoided or eliminated by surprise one at a time. And that's how and why the game *really* starts to shine; Mark of the Ninja is, at heart, a puzzle game (as most of my favorite stealth games are), inherently one where there are multiple solutions to most of the puzzles.
As such, it's not an exaggeration to say that it lives or dies based on the level design. The levels are linear, with distinct starting and ending points and few branching paths, but each section can be approached from numerous directions. The addition of hidden areas and collectable scrolls I could take or leave, but being able to unlock new equipment and Paths" (suits of armor granting special powers) means that the already variable gameplay sprawls out even a little more.
So it's linear
helpfulPercent: but with a huge amount of room for creative puzzle solving for players who have good awareness. Nervous guards can be tricked into shooting their team or tripping and falling off ledges. Killing a sentry or sniper and leaving his body somewhere others will discover it can lure them away from your objective. Often times

reviewText:
The obsession with Ninjas in popular culture began in the '80s when Hollywood produced a few Ninja movies which happened to make a lot of money. As sure as the Sun rises in the East, the smell of profits ensured that a few Ninja movies soon became a plethora and eventually a torrent. Everything martial arts related became popular. Movies by Jean-Claude Van Damme, Steven Seagal and the legendary Chuck Norris inundated the public. Sure, some of them were not bad, but just as a cow produces milk, it also produces manure. Lots of it.

Fortunately for fans, the passage of time hasn't blunted the enthusiasm of Van Damme and Seagal who are still prolific today, producing straight-to-DVD movies with the regularity and consistency of a dyspeptic sybarite with irritable bowel syndrome. As for Seagal[lebeauleblog.com], he is now better known for spending more time at the buffet table than at the training dojo, preparing for his next blockbuster by subsisting on a stringent diet of Buffalo Wings. It is rumoured on the IMDB website that Seagal turned down a part in The Expendables 3 because he wanted to star alongside Harrison Ford in the new Star Wars film as Jabba the Hutt's son.

For anyone who doesn't know, The Expendables is the prestigious action movie franchise where famous action movie stars compete to see who can be more incomprehensible. So far, Slyvester Stallone and Jason Statham are tied for the top spot. In early editions of the DVD (since recalled), a production error dubbed over the actors with these guys and nobody noticed the difference.

Anyway, history buffs might be interested to know that not only is Ninjutsu a venerable art with a long and proud history in Japan, it was practised as far away as the Caribbean, brought there by Ninja-Pirates migrating across the Pacific Ocean. Joining a Ninja clan is simplicity in itself as traditional Ninja membership policies are extremely non-discriminatory as seen in the remarkable documentary Beverly Hills Ninja. In fact, being human is not even a necessary pre-requisite for being a Ninja. Robots, mutants, pet turtles and cheerleaders are all eligible.

As the epitome of martial arts, anyone would think that becoming a Ninja would take strict discipline and many years of intense training, but nothing is further from the truth. Simply yelling Ninja Power Now!" while gesticulating idiotically in the manner of an epileptic mime is all it takes.

In Mark of the Ninja
date: the developers Klei draws on the vast legacy of Ninja mythology to deliver an intriguing 2-D stealth platformer that does justice to the Ninja genre. Your job is to guide Mark
recommended: a slightly fruity human Luddite Ninja
hoursPlayed: on his epic quest to defeat the bad guys by destroying all their lamps. The darkness will create serious Workplace Health and Safety issues and cause severe embarrassment at the next WHS inspection. That'll teach em.\n\nLevels are well designed usually with multiple paths to objectives. Just like in Deus Ex: Human Revolution covert and overt playstyles are supported. The stealth action is incredibly well integrated into the gameplay
voteText: with the option for non-lethal pacifist vegans to ghost through every level without killing a single thing. It's even possible to hide in a box Metal Gear style. Sadly
helpfulPercent: the time-honoured stealth tactic of putting a lampshade on your head and pretending to be a lamp isn't implemented.\n\nWith an engaging narrative
votesHelpful: responsive controls and a beautiful art style that is uniquely Klei
votesTotal: this is the best and only stealth platformer I've ever played."

reviewText:
One of, if not the best stealth game in recent history. It provides all the information required without becoming blatant or easy, and removes the tedium of having to watch long pathing sequences or re-doing long sections due to silly mistakes. At the same time, it offers a myriad of different solutions to any given problem and never uses unfair design to create fake difficulty.

Similarly, its upgrade and customisation system, while not particularly deep, offers further variety and options to be explored and exploited. Add in NG+ and the extra options provided by the Special Editions and the replayability is surprisingly large.

The visuals are clear and simple without becoming simplistic or (overly) cartoony, with proper feedback and warnings on all actions and hazards. The audio similarly provides accurate and crucial feedback on what's going on outside your field of view (especially in NG+ where that field is restricted).

reviewText:
Mark of the Ninja is one of the great stealth games.  It is a 2D game, utilizing Klei's signature art style to tell a surprisingly good story with solid voice acting.  Thankfully it isn't punishingly difficult like Klei's previous Shank games.

Gameplay manages a perfect balance between a fast and fluid action game, and a slow and methodical stealth game.  It's fast enough to please action game lovers, but still offers satisfying stealth mechanics.  You utilize shadows and vents to make your way through levels, with access to a variety of ninja equipment to help you distract and kill enemies.  Klei came up with a very nice vision system, where you can only clearly see what your character can see, with the rest of the screen intelligently blurred out so you not only have to think about your position in relation to lights, but also how well you can see.  Loud enough sounds such as footsteps are visible on the screen thanks to your ninja training.  The game also offers a focus mode which pauses time to allow you to aim and multi-target equipment.  The controls are intuitive and very responsive, at least when using a gamepad.  I have not tested the game with kb/m.

As you progress you can unlock new ninja styles, abilities and killing moves to help you progress through the levels more easily.  Ninja styles have their own strengths and weaknesses and can alter what equipment you are allowed to carry.  I found myself using the standard style for the most part, but it's nice to have options.

The Special Edition DLC includes a new level, a distraction item, and a thrown weapon, as well as a new non-lethal ninja style for those who don't like to kill enemies in stealth games.  All of this equipment can be utilized in the main campaign once the DLC level is completed and does make the game a bit easier since the new items allow you to do some previously impossible actions.  The DLC also adds commentary nodes scattered throughout the game which you can read.  They are unobtrusive for the most part though there are a couple that pop up automatically.  Overall it's a worthwhile DLC but doesn't contain a whole lot of content.

Mark of the Ninja is possibly the best stealth game I have ever played and one of very few games I can find nothing negative to say about.  It is a must play.
voteText: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Should've beaten this game since a long time ago, very good stealth platformer.

This game can be compared as Metal Gear in 2D. You stay under enemy's feet, you climb on the shadow, you walk behind enemies, you hide behind vases/doors. Fighting enemies head on is not recommended and normally would result in lower overall scores after a level ends. To achieve that, you're given various tools like Caltrops or skills like Mark of Serenity or you can even use environmental hazards like spike traps to kill enemies indirectly. Granted, you need some plans ahead to do that, but it's fun when you can pull the strings. There's another option.... to stay quiet and move stealthily, or run like no tomorrow to the checkpoints/objectives ignoring everything. Your call, as the game allows multiple approaches to finish the game.

Game mechanic has some RPG style where you're given talent points and you can assign it to skills (new stealth kill style) and  items (upgrade armor) to be unlocked. This offers some flexibility to suit your playing style.

Graphic is very good and polished. A bit gore here and there but all cartoon-ish so it's ok. The levels are drawn well and the characters do animations when dying (not disappear into thin air), running or terrorized. The game even uses lightning system to calculate detection for AIs. While the AIs are still predictable, it's a good mechanic already. Overall, the game maintains dark appearance throughout and it's suitable with the stealth theme of the game.

As for the sound, it's a quiet game. Only when you alert the guard and trigger the alarm will  the game suddenly play real upbeat sound. Most of the times you'll only hear your footsteps or ambient background sound. The last level music is good, though - and it seems like they put more effort into making it as written in the documentary (DLC).

Story is just classic, not a big invention since sliced bread but the plot is well written. You're a ninja, you're sent on a missions and gotten a tattooed seal that helps but has major drawback on your mind and so on but it keeps me interested in the game - can't tell no spoiler. Most of the times it's told to players via cinematics in-between a level with voice acting included (which is a job well-done as the artists know how to portray the chars they play).

For replayability it lies on New Game Plus+ mode, where enemies basically will one hit KO you and the AI's hearing and eyesight capabilities won't be displayed in screen like in normal mode. In normal mode you're still given a radar in-level for AI's hearing and eyesight capabilities.

Overall difficulty it's sustainable, not too hard not too easy - there are checkpoints in each level so you won't get frustrated. Well, except New Game Plus as it thinks you've beaten the game at least once and have knowledge already.

For playing this game I recommend you to use controller. So far, I find no problem playing with either dinput or xinput based controller. I've tested with Rumblepad 2 and xinput mode F310.

Overall, this is a very polished game saves for occasional glitches as reported here: http://steamcommunity.com/app/214560/discussions/0/541906348038543161/

Well worth it and recommended.

reviewText:
Mark of the Ninja is a perfect example of 2D stealth platforming at its finest. It's obvious from the very beginning of the game that the creators put a lot of thought into how the game's mechanics work, and it shows that the developers really care about the game.

This is not your average stealth game. Everything about it has been tweaked to perfection, and it shows. One thing I really like about this game is the optional commentary, which adds a lot by showing you how the game was created. Of course you can turn the commentary off in the options menu, but I've left it on for my first playthrough and I'm really enjoying it so far.

The music in Mark of the Ninja is very well done, and really contributes to the overall atmosphere of the game. When you're just sneaking around, it's a soothing zen-like experience, but when you're detected by an enemy, it switches to a pulse-pounding combat theme that gets me on edge every time.

The gameplay mechanics are extremely well done. As you progress through the story, you pick up new tools and skills along the way, which adds new depth to the strategy of the game. For example, in the second level you pick up noisemakers which can be thrown to distract a guard, allowing you to sneak up on him for a kill. There are hidden levels, too, that present an entirely new challenge by making you seriously think out your actions before doing anything, as one false step can spell your doom. Fortunately, you're not limited to just a few lives, so if you die a few times it's not going to matter that much.

I'm playing this game with an XBox controller, and I suggest you do the same if you want the best experience. I tried the keyboard/mouse controls for a few minutes, and there's just too much going on so it's really hard to keep track of which key does what, especially when you need precision. And there are a lot of times in this game where you'll need to be very precise. I'm only a few levels into it so far, but I've already encounted quite a few areas where I had to throw a dart to take out a light, then run like hell to hide before the guards noticed, and things like that just don't work as well on a keyboard/mouse control scheme.

For players who care more about the story than the gameplay, Mark of the Ninja won't disappoint you either. The writing is top-notch, and I really enjoy the fact that there are hidden scrolls that give background information to supplement what the NPCs tell you. The cutscenes are beautifully animated in a cartoonish, almost anime-like style that really fits the game perfectly.

If you want a hack-n-slash ninja game, I suggest you look elsewhere. But if you want a true stealth game that will really make you plan out your actions as you jump from one hiding spot to the next, you should be playing Mark of the Ninja right now. I can't remember the last time I had this much fun in a stealth game.

--------------------------------------------------------------------

If you enjoy my reviews, why not follow my curation page? Click here to do that thing!

reviewText:
-Quick Review-
Mark of the Ninja was an enjoyable quick stealth game that does a good job combining stealth, 2D puzzle, action, and combat. The story is quick to play though; you probably will spend a few hours depending on how good you are at staying on target. I tend to collect things so it took me longer than usual but that was okay, because my second time through I was able to wrap up my achievements with relative ease.

-Detailed breakdown review-
Story: Just a fair warning, I might be giving a few details away from the game, it’s short so you probably don’t want to look at the hidden text (put your mouse over it to see). Possibly a spoiler  You are an unnamed ninja who is identified for the tattoos that he wears. These tattoos give him unique and fierce powers, unfortunately as you progress, the poison from these tattoos starts to drive you mad and you no longer can tell the difference between friend and foe.

Game Play:  As you play the game, you get tokens that unlock more abilities and weapons. Without unlocking you get about 4 different ninja abilities, and 5 or 6 different ninja tools. These are enough to solve the puzzles, but for more enjoyment I recommend unlocking the abilities and upgrading your favorite ninja weapons and tools.
Additionally you unlock different costumes that grant you different abilities, however, I found myself sticking to the original balanced outfit.
As I briefly stated, this game is a stealth action puzzle 2D combat game. I didn’t know all those terms could be put together but there you have it. I absolutely loved the game play. The story might have been short but I got a good amount of pleasure out of the game experience, and recommend it to anyone who is a fellow Ninja/Shinobi fan.

Achievements: Something that should be said about the achievements right away, is that to get a complete 100% on the game, you are required to purchase the DLC for the final eight achievements. I haven’t purchased this DLC at this time (02/28/14) but I look forward to maybe seeing a sale on the dlc and I would gladly purchase and try it out.
Regarding the regular achievements, they are fun, enjoyable and mostly straightforward to get. I didn’t look up any guides for the achievements, most of them required either: A) Completing challenges in the game. B) Getting a high enough Score. C) Collecting scrolls inside the game. Once you collected everything the level turned Yellow as a sign of “100%”

Price: Mark of the Ninja is $14.99, plus $4.99 for the DLC. (Get the Special Edition for $17.99) I put in 22 hours into the game. That was two play through and that was about it. I didn’t get very much time out of this game before I had everything and was looking for the next game to play, however I would recommend adding this game to your wish list and waiting for a steam sale. Generally indie games go on sale, so this is probably your best bet.

Conclusion: I loved the game, I loved the story, I loved the controls, I love Shinobi/Ninja, I hated the price and that I need to get DLC to get 100% on the game. You do the math, this game was mostly good with a few disappointments, but on a whole; a pretty great game.


---------------Update after purchasing the DLC and playing---------------
What you get with the DLC: One new skin that gives you a different set of abilities (and also its own unique challenges [no time stop when you use items] ), two different ninja tools, several easy achievements, and an extra level.
I’m really glad I got the DLC on sale because you can get a whole game for $4.99. Additionally I had finished the level and gotten all the new achievements in less than a couple hours. I was disappointed for the high price on the DLC and the little amount of extra play time I put into the game.
I still love the game, but the DLC is definitely a pass, unless you can get the full game or get the DLC on sale.

reviewText:
Mark of the Ninja

In Mark of the Ninja, you'll know what it is to truly be a ninja. You must be silent, agile and clever to outwit your opponents in a world of gorgeous scenery and flowing animation. Marked with cursed tattoos giving you heightened senses, every situation presents you with options.Mark of the ninja is a action, adventure game released on the 16th October 2012 and to be fair. I adore this game, every aspect of this game is fantastic, The Stealth, The Combat, The movement. It makes you feel as if you are a real ninja. I am personally not a big fan of Indie games but this has made me change my mind becuse this game is on a whole new level.

Pros:
- Combat is superb.
- Movement is fabulous.
- Mark of the Ninja is an exceptional stealth-action game.

Cons:
- This game will ruin your life, it is so addictive.

I would recommend this to my friends and i would give this game a 10/10 because as i said, every aspect of this game is awesome and it is just so addictive so WARNING: DO NOT PLAY THIS GAME IF YOU DO NOT WANT ANY ADDICTION TO GAMES.

reviewText:
Mark of the Ninja excels as a side scrolling 2D stealth game. The storyline isn't amazing , but that doesn't really matter here. The gameplay is great and you are in complete control of your environment. You can of course rush through a level, alerting everyone , but the beauty of this game is in surveying the surroundings and using the tools at your disposal to achieve perfection in every level.

The upgrades arrive at a good pace and there is a variety of different tools and outfits you can use to play in a number of different ways. Sound plays a major part in the game, something that many stealth games seem to leave out. There are other collectibles you can find to extend the gameplay even further and a new game plus to increase the challenge again. The campaign itself is remarkably long for a game I considered a small arcade title.

If you are a fan of stealth gameplay and if you especially miss games like Tenchu , then you have to pick this game up. The artwork, mechanics and re-playability make it completely worth it.

reviewText:
Mark of the Ninja is a thoroughly enjoyable sidescrolling stealth platformer that left me surprisingly saddened at it's completion.  Mechanically the game is sound and plays well with the XBOX controller it was designed for.  The music and visuals create a dark atmosphere that suits the work of the Ninja and I particularly enjoyed the crack of thunder, flash of lightning and constant patter of rain while infiltrating Karajan's fortress.

With all the above working to highlight the storyline, there are also plenty of options that allow a player to customize their individual playstyle.  Whether you choose the Path of Silence, Path of Nightmares or any of the other half a dozen Paths available, you will enjoy the way each path's strengths change the experience of the gameplay and provide for replay value to this gem of a game.

And then there is the story of a Ninja Champion, chosen to take on the Mark to save his clan, at the risk of losing his sanity, life and honor.  What will your Fate be?  Buy this game and you won't be disappointed.

reviewText:
Mark of the Ninja is a 2d stealth platformer that applies the stealth genre in unique ways and encourages a wide variety of approaches to tackle a problem. Being a game about ninja, the visual design employs some Japanese style in the levels. There are also other styles depending on the current level, ranging from a modern city, a castle, and the Middle East. This game uses a hand drawn and animated style for objects and people, which look nice visually and stand out from each other. The game's background graphics have intricate designs and distinct silhouettes. Most of the game is shown in a black silhouettes with some highlights. This is both an artistic and a gameplay choice, since lit areas will show the full color of things on screen, while in darkness black silhouettes are shown. The animated cutscenes help drive the story and stay consistent with the style of the game. The cutscene animation quality is great, as if it were an actual show, and has its unique Japanese inspired style like the game's graphics. Overall, the art style leans towards a great animated style with some Japanese influences along with a few other distinct designs.
The music in this game is both a mix of traditional Japanese and contemporary styles. There aren't that many tracks to this game, but the music tends to change dynamically based on actions in the game. There are a few special songs that play at certain parts of the game to heighten a certain mood. Still, the music sounds great here and helps drive the game's style along.

The story of Mark of the Ninja features an unnamed ninja under the control of Azai, his master, on a mission to assassinate the owner of a company called Hessian. Along the way the player meets up with Ora, a female ninja who guides the player along in the game and Dosan, an artist who gives the playable unnamed ninja special tattoos. These tattoos grant special powers to the bearer, but cause them delve into madness if they have the mark for too long.
There is obviously more to the plot without spoiling it, but the story for Mark of the Ninja is thought out well and has excellent twists and turns throughout the whole game. The animated cutscenes occur mainly between levels and help drive the story, along with special levels designed to advance the story further. The strong story will keep players on the game, along with its excellent gameplay.

This game takes the stealth genre and applies it to a 2d platformer with wildy amazing results. For starters, the player needs to take advantage of line of sight, lighting, and sound to slip by undetected. These three things each have their own visual cues, ranging from blurring, silhouettes, and circles to represent sound that others can hear. The player can kill enemies, but it usually has to be done using stealth. Going at an enemy head on where they can see you is a surefire way to get killed. Along the way, the player can use special tools or moves to help kill or sneak by enemies, and can be upgraded or unlocked with special tokens earned from playing the game. Enemies can be distracted, take notice of you, and can even be terrified. Knowing the best course of action when the enemy behavior changes is vital. Sometimes, a puzzle needs to be solved to advance, which is based on some special mechanics seen throughout the levels. The game does open up a wide amount of options to get through an area with complex tools to accomplish the task. Solving a puzzle or navigating a room of enemies successfully feels rewarding, and it's not just the assassination animations looking cool too. Taking the stealth genre and putting it in a 2d game is well done here, as you do have many options and tools to use for a very engaging experience.

Mark of the Ninja nails its 2d stealth platforming down, and it also has an animated visual style and a well written story. You will definitely enjoy all three of these parts of the game for the high quality demonstrated in this game as a whole.

reviewText:
I highly recommend this game to any stealth/action. Especially those who don't mind the minor puzzle, or two. The premise was executed very well.

Even at full price I think the game is worth it.

The artwork is very well done, and creates a unique atmosphere/environment. The hand-drawn graphics, and animations are very well done. (except for notably a helicopter in the game looks freaking HORRIBLE)
The music has some moments where it is pretty good too.

the abilities, and upgrades are pretty awesome. Some of the levels are great, I especially like the later ones.

Its fun, and very easy to get into. There are a few moments which will make you think, but overall this should be approacable by anyone familiar to gaming.

The game is not too short, and doesn't run on. Decent length, I got 93% of the achievements, and completeled the game fully short of new game plus.

The controls were smooth, took little-to-no getting use to.  Very little bugs, although the occasional checkpoint bug which sticks you in a loop due to some strange (failing stipulation) for instance: get a checkpoint  1 sec before someone spots you, and when they do mission failure. (don't have time to escape, have to restart level) But that was really no biggie.


The Modern Ninja setting was cool, but I would like to see some Espionage, spy, military, CIA stype stuff in a game kinda like this. Maybe with slightly better graphics (just slightly), or better effects.

If this game is ever on sale, there really isn't a reason you shouldn't try it.  Unless you just don't like Ninja's, or stealth games at all.

reviewText: I have only beat around 4 levels so far in the game, but I can already say that this game is pretty damn good. The controls are very easy and responsive. The gameplay is quite simple as well, but also innovative. There are many different ways to beat the levels, which results in a lot of replayability. You can also unlock new upgrades and attacks, which makes you want to perfect every single level to get enough points for all the upgrades. The stealth mechanic works really good as well, if you're into stealth games then I can assure you that you will love this game. The good thing about this game is that you can decide if you want to kill every single guard or if you just want to try sneaking past them. Basically, you can decide if you want to go lethal or non-lethal.\n\nDo I recommend this game? YES YES AND YES, I think you should definitely buy it.

reviewText:
This has got to be the best stealth game I have ever played in my life, and is one of the best games I've played this year. A ridiculously well-done masterpiece, from start to finish. The stealth mechanics are amazing as this is the only game where sound, visibility and movement indicators are so well done. You always know if you will be spotted or not. Also, Mark of the Ninja has great variety, as you can complete each mission how you want it. Want to become a merciless killing machine, with upgraded armor and health regeneration? You got it! Want to become the living shadow, making almost no noise at all and flying through obstacles undetected? Check! Want to strike endless fear to your enemies, hanging both dead and alive while slaughtering terrorized foes like pigs? How about a no-killing policy, where you don't even have a sword? Check, check, check! A dozen of absolutely different gadgets also add to variety and make every playthrough unique. If you want, you can carefully lay down mines on the path and lure enemies with firecrackers, killing the guards remotely, or you can throw a hallucination dart and make the foes shoot each other down. Hell, you can even take a plain old cardboard box, hide inside it and just wait for the kill!
Not only the playstyles and gadgets, but also the levels themselves add to the variety. If you see a heavily guarded corridor, you can always rush underground, trying to avoid various traps, but without the necessity of dealing with the guards, Or you can rush through the door, throw a smokebomb and massacre everyone. Of course, you might just climb on the roof, go through the ventilation chamber and lure off the enemies and murder them one by one. Or, you could just.... well, you get the idea. Each level can be beaten in so many ways it can be hard to count.
Surprisingly, there's also a lot of diferent enemies. From your average short-sighted guard, who easily panicks to cybernetic assassins who detect your presence from afar to snipers who take you down in one shot. There's numerous types of guards, each of them must be dealt in a different way. The enemies also look really great, and so we come in to our second part of the game...
...the graphics. They are amazing. The levels look gorgeous in such a way, and as I mentioned, various stealth-related indicators look and fit here really well. Areas that you have no vision off have this black and white mist. Sound indicators have different shapes, sizes and colors depending on the strenght of the sound. Thus, you will always differ a footstep from a gong going off.
Speaking of which, the sound in this game is great. It fits the atmosphere really well and the swish, swoosh of a stealth kill feels ever so satisfying. The music is great as well, it differs in both the tone and intensity if you are slowly climbing the walls or running away after you've been spotted.
The controls are one of the best in a 2D sidescroller as they can get. The character will almost always do exactly what you want to, whether this could be hanging off a ledge without jumping off or doing a tricky jump off a cliff in order to land right behind a guard.  This makes even the hardest challenges force you to keep going or try a different aproach without any rage, as any deaths are because of your poor judgement and not bad controls.
The challenges are incredible. Most puzzles in MotN will normally be solved in under a minute, but if that sounds too easy to you, and it should, there's always a sacred gong in every level. It offer a really hard challenge, based on the thematic of the level, forcing the most out of your problem solving, finger dexterity or ninja skill usage. The challenges are hard, and most of them will require more than five minutes each, but they are never unfair or unsolvable.
There's so much I haven't talked about, like the great storyline, Mark Powers and many more things, but I think every single one of you should see for yourselves.
Klei Entertainment did a really good job.
Recomended to buy.

reviewText: I love stealth games that gives me tools to finish levels in multiple ways: without killing anyone or being seen or clear level of life. Mark of the ninja offers just that, a game that could be finished in many different ways, you can terrorize your enemies and let them shoot each other, you can   brutally murder all guards on the level, you might want a bit of challenge and try pacifist run. Mark of the Ninja offers all this and more. It is a game with simple controls, simple mechanics and yet I finished it least 3 times.\nThe story follows the silent protagonist which has a tattoo's that gives him supernatural abilities such as teleportation, freezing time seeing through walls etc. As lore explains such power comes with great responsibility, the ninja must to end his life after the mission because he might become mentally unstable due ink that is used for tatoo's. It's tradition that comes back from ancestors. At the begining of the game you are awaken by fellow ninja Ora which guides you through first level. Apparantly your home is being attacked by some soldiers for unknown reasons. Once you finish the level your real mission begins: find who attacked your home and dispose of him.\nGame features 12 levels unique levels, fun gameplay, replay value and good story. I highly recommend getting this game. 8/10

reviewText:
A really fun stealth game that is polished to a brilliant shine. Plenty of levels to experience, plenty of tricks and weapons you can use to complete objectives. Whether its taking down targets silently without killing them or going on a massive murder-spree, the game supports it. (To a point). Add on multiple ways to approach a problem and this game just rocks. The story is a bit weird and that ending even more so. While you can burn through the main campaign in around 10 hours, you should also consider trying to get all the achievements and optional objectives, as they really flesh out the entire experience. I'm not one to say that often either so, something to keep in mind.

For a 2D game, it has a surprising amount of PC settings that  you wouldn't normally expect. You can check them all out here: http://pcgamingwiki.com/wiki/File:Mark_of_the_Ninja_video_settings.png. The DLC comes with a new level, more items and new playstyles for non-lethal takedowns in the original game. Definitely worth picking it up and/or the Special Edition of Mark of the Ninja.

This is quite the engaging experience and makes Mark of the Ninja one of my favorite stealth games. Klei's artstyle and attention to detail is in fine form and you're missing out if you don't get it.

reviewText:
If you like to hide in the dark and stab guards in the neck, this is probably the best dark hiding, neck stabbing 2D platformer around. With plenty of ways to approach each situation, this game provides you many variables. This game also features the return of near-sighted guards that stop caring about broken lights after a bit.

Well animated like various childhood cartoons but with blood, this game looks great.

Play as a ninja with a burning tattoo the allows him to aim darts with out worrying about taking time to aim darts, on a quest to destroy evil in the coolest way you've never seen: Stealth Assassinations with QTE mouse sliding
Get more points by hiding behind things, killing things, hiding bodies, dropping lights on guards heads, and many more things.

This game also has a lady ninja to guide you. And if we know anything about lady ninjas. It's that games with them tend to be great.

reviewText: In most games I cringe at the idea of going full stealth simply because of the dull, slow and eventually boring environment thats normally required to succeed.  Mark of the Ninja is very different.  This game does stealth right, point blankly.  The entertainment value remains high throughout, even while you sneak around, remaining quiet and trying to actually be a ninja.  And eventually you have enough tools and experience at your disposal to rarely have to stop moving, even in stealth with guards all around you.  Add to that the fact that the story is very well written, full of twists, betrayal and difficult moral decisions, and this is definitely a game I recommend.

reviewText:
Mark of the Ninja is a great game marred only by a few questionable design choices. It's clearly taken cues from the stealth games that came before it, and applied what it learned to make a highly enjoyable game that avoids a lot of the frustrations that can, and have, plagued the genre.

You play as an unnamed ninja who possesses mysterious tattoos that give him superhuman abilities. Abilities that come in handy when your ninja clan is slaughtered and you start out on a quest for revenge. It's a cliche setup, and for the most part the game seems to be OK with that, focusing more on making you feel like a ninja than telling you a deep story. Midway through however, the game's priorities seem to shift and it suddenly wants to be thoughtful and engaging, but without the character and story development needed for something like that. It's just there with little substance and unlikely to leave the impact that it seems to want to by the end.

But that's OK, because it makes up for that shortcoming with excellent design, responsive controls, and a huge amount of player freedom. Each level is scored, has collectables, secret rooms, and level specific challenges. All of which lead to character upgrades and alternate costumes that set up a sort of risk/reward type of strategy as you decide which bonuses are worth which penalties.

Combine that with the variety of ways any given situation can be approached (levels are large, layered, and full of toys to play with), and you have a game that rewards experimentation and exploration, and doesn't punish you for playing the way you want to. Most of time. Unfortunately, as the game progresses toward the end, it begins to push the player into a specific play style, and then outright forces another, eliminating the freedom of play that it carries through most of the game. The story may be the worst part of the game, but this shortcoming is the most disappointing.

Still, the game is highly enjoyable. Your character responds quickly to your commands and features such as the need to press the jump or run key to descend from a ledge (keeping you from accidentally falling into enemy sight lines) limits frustration. 95% of the time, if you're caught, it's your fault, which is how it should be.

Mark of the Ninja is definitely a blast to play. It's smooth, stylistic, and challenging without being unfair. It's few faults don't keep it from being an overall highly enjoyable experience.

reviewText:
I always wanted to be a NInja. This game is pretty much the closest thing I have got to achieving this goal. The best bit about this game is it really makes you feel like a ninja, without the  use of fancy 3D, realistic graphics. Whether you want to be the stealthy, sneak-by everything ninja or the katana wielding meat grinder, this game will make you feel very Ninja-like. The stealth mechanics are some of the best I've ever seen, better than that in some 3d games, with great AI, multiple routes and the fact every move, every noise you make could be your downfall.

This is only complimented by the art style, which is nothing short of beautiful. Factors like noise, enemy awareness and enemy vision are all clearly displayed in a neat way that doesn't detract from the art style at all. The Animations and cutscenes are excellent and while the story isn't brilliant, the gameplay more than makes up for it.

So, if you are a fan of the stealth genre, do yourself a favour and buy this game, otherwise you are truly missing out on one of the best stealth games of this generation. 10/10

reviewText: Whether it's the optional course of action as in Deus Ex, or a necessary survival element as in Thief, stealth mechanics in games always add an exciting way to play that requires a player to think more tactfully than most game experiences.  In my exploration of such games, I have yet to come across one that accomplishes this is such a simple, yet successful manner as Mark of the Ninja.  Using an easy to understand system of darkness, distractions, and assassination, the surface level of it's gameplay does not have anything to make it stand out.  Rather than attempt to accomplish too much though, Mark of the Ninja demonstrates a seamless mastery of it's stealth system, and allows the player to approach it from many varying methods of completion.  While level objectives are static, the addition of varying skills, items, and costumes allow the player to adopt unique strategies to complete these in a variety of ways–whether that be through slaying guards, utilizing terror, or sneaking your way through every room.  Unfortunately the story falls short of the expectation set up by the rest of the game, but is engaging enough to push the game in the intended direction and motivate the player to complete missions.  Overall, Mark of the Ninja offers a fantastic change of pace that I would recommend to anyone remotely interested, and sets itself up as a benchmark for what  stealth games should strive to be.

reviewText:
MotN is one of the most well crafted indie games I ever played. This game is about stealth, analyzing the situation, and use the most suitable tactics to outwit your enemies, which presented in 2D platformer.

I highly recommend this game to anyone, especially for fans of stealth genre game.
And if you want to unlock all achievements, you need to buy Special Edition DLC, which contain new non-lethal takedown, new items, and level.

reviewText: This game really fills a niche I have been wanting filled since Tenchu! The gameplay is fantastic, and only gets more amazing each level. The multitude of ways to attack each situation is really incredible. I enjoyed leaving a blood bath in my wake, but you can avoid the guards etc. completely if you are stealthy enough. The upgrades and number of tools at your disposal really give you a solid sense of progression and lead to some tough decisions at the start of missions. Unlocking new suits has some really interesting effects and make you really think about what it is you are aiming to do, whether it be full stealth, or something in the middle, up to mass slaughter. The story is interesting, but the gameplay is why you must buy this game. 9/10 .

reviewText:
One shade separated from another, flashed through a corridor and clung to a massive pillar. A guard blinked and fixed his aim on that point. With a slow motion he switched on a flashlight mounted on his submachine gun and blinked again. Light beamed the pillar forcefully causing the myriads of shadows stampede.

I am losing my senses - the guard thought.

A feint movement of shade produced a blow so mighty yet discrete at the same time. The air was still when the guard collapsed.

This is Mark of the Ninja. Precise execution, flawless mechanics and rapid tempo of this hit took its toll not only on unlucky guard. I was blown away too. Every single area of this game shines brightly and works extremely well together. Architecture of levels, atmospheric visuals and sound, brilliant ideas in mechanics, simple but existing story, skills, upgrades, unlocks and sleeping dogs. Not to prolong any more with the details you can probably find in any other review I can simply say: get it!

Mark of the Ninja is the best game in it's genre of platformers (stealthy one here). It is also one of the best games ever in my private ranking. After you finish a last level of it and read cool developer diaries just start again in a new game+ because delving into virtual 2d world has never been so fascinating.

Ninja style recommendation.

reviewText:
A 2D side-scroller you do not see much these days. In fact, while many of these games remind you of Mario or Contra, games in which you were actively engaged in combat, Mark of The Ninja puts a lot of emphasis on stealth instead. Attacking your foes up front is instant death. Your best bet is to lay traps or to approach from the shadow which is your best friend in this game. There are a handful of levels and the further you get the more patience is required from your side: each move how you take down your enemies should be planned carefully.

I liked the learning curve in Mark of The Ninja. The levels got more and more difficult gradually - at no point did I feel the AI was cheating and completing a mission was impossible. The higher difficulty levels along with the Special Edition released not long ago increase the already decent replayability.

A unique, stealth-based side-scroller I can recommend to everybody. Not just the fans of the genre but those longing for something new and original.

reviewText: Mark of the Ninja" is an excellent game.  Initially
date: I didn't want to buy it since I'm not really one for side-scrolling platformers.  But
hoursPlayed: I caught it at $10.48 and bought it.  I'm very pleased.  Why am I so happy with it?  Because the side-scrolling platforming is not all that obtrusive and the big driver in the game is stealth.  As an added bonus
voteText: much of it (though not all) can be played without killing people.  And
helpfulPercent: since it took me a total of 59 hours to finish the base game and get all the Achievements (42 hours to finish the first run through
votesHelpful: plus another 17 hours to finish it in New Game Plus mode)
votesTotal: the money I spent was well worth it.  With the amount of gameplay you get out of the game
votesFunny: it's worth it even at the current list price of $14.99.\n\nI do have some minor issues with the game.  Most irritating is that the DLC's Achievements are lumped in with the base game's even if you don't own the DLC.  So
commentsCount: even though I  don't yet have the DLC
column16: and have completed 100% of the base game's Achievements
column17: Steam only shows a completion rate of 79%.  The most serious issue is with the mechanism used for you to return to the levels you've completed.  I (and many others) initially couldn't seem to return to my last level.  It turns out that the obvious scrolling to what you think are the levels only takes you to what are actually *areas*.  The specific levels are represented by the drawings of buildings at the top of those area screens.  So
column18: you scroll to the area and then click on the building (or level) you want.\n\nAs for quibbles
column19: there are several places where the game saves a waypoint (or even finishes a level) without warning and

reviewText: I played late and have yet to tackle New Game+, but Mark of the Ninja has to be one of my top games of 2012.  It offers all of the stealthy exploration and interaction of the Batman Arkham series without the cruft.  The game is mission-based, but each mission allows backtracking and can be replayed later to find missing items, try out different tactics or aim for a higher score.  You can even take advantage of restarting from mid-mission checkpoints when failing to pull off whatever you intended.  Upgrades can be earned, but are not required.  While I tended to focus on takedowns and smoke bombs, there's plenty of room to experiment.  It's a giant, segmented playground and I love it.

reviewText:
Best 2-D sidescrolling game ever. I would play it faaaar more than I have already, but TF2 is too addicting. This is absolutely my second-favorite game in my library though.

It's not for everyone though. If you like all-out fighting, you probably won't be interested in this.
If you like stealth, sneaking, and thoughtful attacks, this is the game for you. Honestly, I love almost everything about this game. The soundtrack, the sounds, the controls, the story, everything is amazing.

Totally worth the money, but then again I got it really cheap. If you're not sure, you could wait for a sale or try out Steam's new refund policy if you don't like it... either way, I highly doubt you'll be disappointed.

reviewText:
Mark of the Ninja is a great game marred only by a few questionable design choices. It's clearly taken cues from the stealth games that came before it, and applied what it learned to make a highly enjoyable game that avoids a lot of the frustrations that can, and have, plagued the genre.

You play as an unnamed ninja who possesses mysterious tattoos that give him superhuman abilities. Abilities that come in handy when your ninja clan is slaughtered and you start out on a quest for revenge. It's a cliche setup, and for the most part the game seems to be OK with that, focusing more on making you feel like a ninja than telling you a deep story. Midway through however, the game's priorities seem to shift and it suddenly wants to be thoughtful and engaging, but without the character and story development needed for something like that. It's just there with little substance and unlikely to leave the impact that it seems to want to by the end.

But that's OK, because it makes up for that shortcoming with excellent design, responsive controls, and a huge amount of player freedom. Each level is scored, has collectables, secret rooms, and level specific challenges. All of which lead to character upgrades and alternate costumes that set up a sort of risk/reward type of strategy as you decide which bonuses are worth which penalties.

Combine that with the variety of ways any given situation can be approached (levels are large, layered, and full of toys to play with), and you have a game that rewards experimentation and exploration, and doesn't punish you for playing the way you want to. Most of time. Unfortunately, as the game progresses toward the end, it begins to push the player into a specific play style, and then outright forces another, eliminating the freedom of play that it carries through most of the game. The story may be the worst part of the game, but this shortcoming is the most disappointing.

Still, the game is highly enjoyable. Your character responds quickly to your commands and features such as the need to press the jump or run key to descend from a ledge (keeping you from accidentally falling into enemy sight lines) limits frustration. 95% of the time, if you're caught, it's your fault, which is how it should be.

Mark of the Ninja is definitely a blast to play. It's smooth, stylistic, and challenging without being unfair. It's few faults don't keep it from being an overall highly enjoyable experience.

reviewText:
I always wanted to be a NInja. This game is pretty much the closest thing I have got to achieving this goal. The best bit about this game is it really makes you feel like a ninja, without the  use of fancy 3D, realistic graphics. Whether you want to be the stealthy, sneak-by everything ninja or the katana wielding meat grinder, this game will make you feel very Ninja-like. The stealth mechanics are some of the best I've ever seen, better than that in some 3d games, with great AI, multiple routes and the fact every move, every noise you make could be your downfall.

This is only complimented by the art style, which is nothing short of beautiful. Factors like noise, enemy awareness and enemy vision are all clearly displayed in a neat way that doesn't detract from the art style at all. The Animations and cutscenes are excellent and while the story isn't brilliant, the gameplay more than makes up for it.

So, if you are a fan of the stealth genre, do yourself a favour and buy this game, otherwise you are truly missing out on one of the best stealth games of this generation. 10/10
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Whether it's the optional course of action as in Deus Ex, or a necessary survival element as in Thief, stealth mechanics in games always add an exciting way to play that requires a player to think more tactfully than most game experiences.  In my exploration of such games, I have yet to come across one that accomplishes this is such a simple, yet successful manner as Mark of the Ninja.  Using an easy to understand system of darkness, distractions, and assassination, the surface level of it's gameplay does not have anything to make it stand out.  Rather than attempt to accomplish too much though, Mark of the Ninja demonstrates a seamless mastery of it's stealth system, and allows the player to approach it from many varying methods of completion.  While level objectives are static, the addition of varying skills, items, and costumes allow the player to adopt unique strategies to complete these in a variety of ways–whether that be through slaying guards, utilizing terror, or sneaking your way through every room.  Unfortunately the story falls short of the expectation set up by the rest of the game, but is engaging enough to push the game in the intended direction and motivate the player to complete missions.  Overall, Mark of the Ninja offers a fantastic change of pace that I would recommend to anyone remotely interested, and sets itself up as a benchmark for what  stealth games should strive to be.

reviewText:
MotN is one of the most well crafted indie games I ever played. This game is about stealth, analyzing the situation, and use the most suitable tactics to outwit your enemies, which presented in 2D platformer.
One of the most interesting feature of this game is we can finish the level using more than single method. Whether it's pure stealth run without killing anyone, or leaving dead bodies and terror along your path, it's all viable.
I highly recommend this game to anyone, especially for fans of stealth genre game.
And if you want to unlock all achievements, you need to buy Special Edition DLC, which contain new non-lethal takedown, new items, and level.

reviewText: This game really fills a niche I have been wanting filled since Tenchu! The gameplay is fantastic, and only gets more amazing each level. The multitude of ways to attack each situation is really incredible. I enjoyed leaving a blood bath in my wake, but you can avoid the guards etc. completely if you are stealthy enough. The upgrades and number of tools at your disposal really give you a solid sense of progression and lead to some tough decisions at the start of missions. Unlocking new suits has some really interesting effects and make you really think about what it is you are aiming to do, whether it be full stealth, or something in the middle, up to mass slaughter. The story is interesting, but the gameplay is why you must buy this game. 9/10 .

reviewText:
Mark of the ninja is a 2D stealth-action platformer, and it is my favourite stealth game, although it is not without its flaws. While it may not have the most original story, it is your standard western ninja-flick, the beautiful animation makes the cutscenes stunning and engaging, and the talented voice actors make it even better. The gameplay itself is quite unique, because in most stealth games it is always a gamble about how far the guards can see or hear, or how far the grenade you've thrown will go etc. However, in Mark of the Ninja, it tells you all of these things that you need to know, making most, if not all, deaths simply user error, and not bad game design making it unfair.

In the game you can choose your playstyle: sneaky sneaky, or kill people- and non leathal take-downs with the special dlc- and the game gives you upgrade paths for all of those playstyles. However, I feel that the game is a bit indecisive about the upgrades and playstyles, because while you get loads of points for completing a mission without killing people or being spotted, most of the upgrades are for the violent path, with far less benifitting a stealth approach. Personally,
I prefer the violent path, purely because of the great takedown animations.

The presentaion and artstyle of this game is amazing. It really adds to the atmosphere, and the fact that it is all hand drawn makes it even better to look at. When it comes to Klei's games (the company that made Mark of the Ninja) they have a really unique and eye-catching art style to all of their games, whilest all of it is unique, it still has that similar, colourful theme.

Overall, I would recommend this game to anyone who even has a passing interest in the stealth genre, and for stealth verterans looking for a challenge in the New Game Plus mode. It is also a good entry level stealth game, catering well for beginners and people who have only just discovered the genre.

Pros

Excellent gameplay
Original art style
Good for beginners and veterans
Cons

Unoriginal story
Some bugs and glitches
Score

8.5/10
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
An excellent puzzle-platformer that oozes style, and features brilliant stealth-based gameplay. The animation and art style are bot fantastic, the cutscenes and story are well done, and the 'feel' is just right.

Some of the levels, depending on your desire to achieve 100% completion, will cause you to pull your hair out. Don't fret, as each stage can be replayed upon completion. There's also a New Game+ mode for those who crave an even greater challenge.

There are a few nitpicks. First, the game sometime doesn't recognize (i.e. award points for) hidden bodies, or certain other tasks. The handy-dandy 'restart from checkpoint' option nearly always solved this for me. Still, I thought it wise to give you all a head's up. Second, and I blame Steam/Steam Cloud for this, I -- and many others if you check Google -- lost my save at one point, completely negating approximately six hours of playtime. Mark of the Ninja is so good, I didn't really have an issue replaying it, but -- again -- it's worth mentioning.

Perhaps due to the need to replay a significant portion of the  game, I do wish it was a level or two shorter. By the end, I was a little burned out. Nonetheless, I wholeheartedly recommend purchasing this title.

reviewText: For the price, this beats any other AAA game out there. It's essentaily a 2D stealth game done right. The graphics are beautiful and the sound effects are spot on. I highly recommend this game for anybody who is into retro 2D side scrollers with a challange or if you just love stealth games like Metal Gear Solid but with a 2D twist. The controls are very fluent when playing this with a gamepad and you always have the sense that you are in control of the character. I also played this game with mouse/keyboard to give it a try and I had the same result. The controls were always spot on. They were never stiff or fidgety. My only complaint is that during the level their is no music, just the ambient sounds of the background and you. There is a reason for this however, to be aware of your surroundings. This game does have replay value if you want to unlock everything such as items and ninja outfits. I have unlocked everything and even gotten every single achievement in the game. Onces that is finish there is almost no sense to go back to this game but even so I spent over 20 hours playing it. That is more time spent on this game than Call of Duty Modern Warfare 2, 3 and Aliens: Colonial Marines combined!  That is $180 worth of games! This game is under $20 and I bet you will have more fun and spent more time on this game then those games. I give this game a 9.5/10.

reviewText:
Has the art of the ninja ever called to you? Have you ever wanted magical tattoo’s that give you supernatural powers? Then this is the game for you.

Wow what a looker, the art style of this game is gorgeous. It is very reminiscent of a comic book, one with a boat load of blood an action to boot.

The game play is fluid and the controls are pin perfect, of course they would have to be to get through some of the more challenging areas. Speaking of challenging, mark of the Ninja has just enough to keep you entertained and not rip your hair out.

The Story is great, not in depth but does it really have to be when all you want to do is hack up bad guys and be the “hero”. I loved it from start to finish; the same can be said for the characters. Each has their place and they all add to the experience.

Amazing game from start to finish, It’s so much fun and I spent hours playing it in different ways just to experience all the various play styles and ways to maim and murder.

I fully recommend this to everyone; it’s one of my favorites.

Have fun ^_^

reviewText: It's hard to write this review other than saying, Just buy it!"\n\nI got it for $4.49 with the special edition package during the Winter Sale. If I had known about this game before hand
date:
I would have paid full price; it's that good.

My Impression:
I walked in expecting of a 2D stealth-action game with great mechanics and a fair amount of freedom with each level. This offered that. I expected to be able to stealth around a platformer as a ninja and kill my opponents. This offered that. It met my expectations.

Positive:
+ Best in genre of 2D stealth games
+ Great graphics
+ Great mechanics with different ways of killing your opponents
+ Different builds you can use (it's possible to beat any map with an build
recommended:
whatever suits your style)
+ Strategy involved in using objects and builds to kill you opponents
+ Replayability with the scoring of each "chapter"

Cons:
- The story starts off slow
- Have to finish the game to appreciate the story

Reason for 10/10:
Lack of an immersive story

9/10

Recommended to anyone who just wants to have fun. It's been awhile since a game was just fun to me. Most are actually fun but usually have sort of grind mechanic which can reduce how much I enjoy the game. This game keeps me entertained and wanting more. Easy recommendation."

reviewText:
One of the best stealth games. Absolutely MUST GET IT. The greatest thing about this game is that it will make you feel like a ninja.

Pros:
+ Great stealth mechanics. Controls are also very responsive.
+ High replayability: Different tools and gadgets are available and there are multiple ways to approach a situation. You are rewarded for completing a mission without killing any enemies but there are also rewards if you choose to kill them. So you can play in your style.
+ So many ways to distract, manipulate and hide from the guards. You can also manipulate the environment, such as breaking lights.
+ So many ways to kill the guards. From behind doors, from hiding spots, from below, from top... all done in great animations.
+ Beautiful artwork and sounds.
+ Very atmospheric game. Sucks you into the action. You really feel like a ninja.
+ Some witty puzzles and challenge (bonus) levels are also there.

Cons:
Need more games like this.

reviewText:
Highly, highly recommended to anyone who is a fan of stealth games.

Its strongest aspect without a doubt is the level design, allowing the player to clear each stage of the game in a variety of ways (note that unlockable moves and throwable distraction/attack items further add to this throughout the game). Having tried to clear levels in several of those different ways during my playthrough - from only distracting guards (without killing anyone) to only getting rid of those in my way to making sure every single last one was dead before moving on - I can conclude that all of those options felt viable, challenging and satisfactory (once completed) in their own way. You're also rewarded as a player for pretty much anything positive you do (killing an opponent, staying undetected while an opponent passes by, successfully distracting an opponent, etc.), so no complaints there.

Furthermore, the game does a good job of throwing in new types of enemies or other obstacles (e.g. poison gas, explosives) whenever you think you've seen it all, and although the story for the most part is not overly impressive the ending made me appreciate it a whole lot more (dw, won't spoil anything).

As a final sidenote, I should note that I found messing with guards and leaving them in a state of terror (usually happens when they see another guard step into a trap and die in front of their eyes) absolutely hilarious, 10/10 would do again.

reviewText: It will be a pleasant surprise when you play through this game and realize that you're getting much more than you expected initially. Mark of the NInja gives off the vibe of being a simple stealth platformer but that exterior covers a game where your choice carries weight. Few games lately have choices within the gameplay that you are forced to make within a split second that will carry enough weight to make you ponder whether or not you approached it correctly". This certainly doesn't detract from the flow of the story that will pull you in and carry you to the end before you even realized hours upon hours have passed.\n\nHonestly I can't recommend a game like this enough to people who are looking for a well priced experience that will stick with you for some time to come."

reviewText: I love stealth games. I love platformers. Then I found Mark of the Ninja. This is the one of the best platformer stealth games I have played so far. It is challenging in certain stages, it has bits of puzzle solving, and requires strategy in certain parts of the game depending on your play style. You can either kill every one you see or simply sneak past the entire stages utilizing all of the items you have for both Distractions items or Attack/Lethal items as you like. reviewText: It's hard to write this review other than saying, Just buy it!"\n\nI got it for $4.49 with the special edition package during the Winter Sale. If I had known about this game before hand
date:
I would have paid full price; it's that good.

My Impression:
I walked in expecting of a 2D stealth-action game with great mechanics and a fair amount of freedom with each level. This offered that. I expected to be able to stealth around a platformer as a ninja and kill my opponents. This offered that. It met my expectations.

Positive:
+ Best in genre of 2D stealth games
+ Great graphics
+ Great mechanics with different ways of killing your opponents
+ Different builds you can use (it's possible to beat any map with an build
recommended:
whatever suits your style)
+ Strategy involved in using objects and builds to kill you opponents
+ Replayability with the scoring of each "chapter"

Cons:
- The story starts off slow
- Have to finish the game to appreciate the story

Reason for 10/10:
Lack of an immersive story

9/10

Recommended to anyone who just wants to have fun. It's been awhile since a game was just fun to me. Most are actually fun but usually have sort of grind mechanic which can reduce how much I enjoy the game. This game keeps me entertained and wanting more. Easy recommendation."

reviewText: In Mark of the Ninja, you play as a hardworking family man who is living the American dream. On level 2, when your wife tasks you with taking out the recycling, the game takes a dark turn as you, the player, discovers on the door of your 4 bedroom suburban home the dreaded mark of the ninja. Ancient Japanese folklore states that those who once lived a dark path cannot escape their judgement among the gods, and it is the task of the order of the ninja to mark such people and bring them to justice. In levels 3-10 you proceed to dodge the ninja's attempts on your life such as while waiting in line at the grocery or having to outrun the ninja while you're getting your license renewed at the department of motor vehicles while still having to perform up-to-par as a driver to the ministry's expectations. Narratively, the game is very interesting, as the player discovers more about their dark past and wrestles with mature themes such as forgiveness and regret.\n\nWhile the mark of the ninja is very dangerous to get in real life, don't be afraid to get the mark of the ninja on steam, you'll be safe from the ninja on steam.

reviewText: Very surprised by how well it was done for being a small indie sidescroller. There are many cool ways to kill, and many different tools in your arsenal. All aspects of the stealth aspect are done right, from light, to sight, to sound. There are a few minor problems. I would do the same part over numerous times and do the exact same thing and I would get caught sometimes and not others. There is sometimes a flaw in the lack of consistency. The levels all seem very similar as the terrain is black and there isn't much of a different to to notice. The length is not bad for being a lower costing price. It is nice how there are multiple ways to go and get to a part. This also backfires however, when you are supposed to find things scattered about the level to complete challenges it is usually all but impossible with how many different ways there are to go which can make the levels confusing. Since you stealth kill people very often, it gets boring to see the same 3 animations for 7 hours. Theres really only way to kill people and it leaves very littile in improvisation. Most of the abilities are locked through the entire game which makes sense. I think it is meant to be so you replay but that is a cheap way of doing it as I would like to see what my guy can do through the game. You also get very little honor to unlock new things and many of the abilities are simple upgrades on equipment and usually uninspired. The controls sometimes screw up. Certain times I would want to jump down and it would make me go into a vent instead. Other times I want to jump off a ledge and it would make me stick to it and just transfer to the underside. Other times I would be right behind someone to stealth kill them and I would press the button and it would just hit them for no reason. All-in-all this game deserved the good reviews that it got and  itusually does stealth right. Once again a lesson for all those ♥♥♥♥ indie developers that keep putting out 1990's pixelated japense rpgs or other crappy aracade side-scrolling shooters. You can make an inspired and original game. No need for more games that look like ♥♥♥♥ and are the same as every other one out there. 8.5/10
