reviewText:
Hell friggin' yeah!

This oughta be my favorite stealth game ever and I'm gonna explain in a few lines why I love it so much. First off, its art style reminds me of cartoon TV shows I used to enjoy watching through my childhood years, like Avatar and many Cartoon Network-based shows, so that's a big plus for me. Then the gameplay - the controls are very responsive, its mechanics aren't hard to get a hold of, every level feels like a bit of something new and there's mostly always several options to deal with any problem that the player has to face so the game never gets boring. Manipulating, terrorizing and executing enemies is pretty satisyfing, and many different execution moves and several animations for each make sure that killing people doesn't become a tedious chore. Checkpoints aren't scarce and shops are always accessible in case the player wants to switch loadouts mid-mission. Exploration feels rewarding thanks to the side-objectives that every mission has and as well as the goodies that can be found at distant parts of any level, like challenge rooms. The soundwork is freakin' A, especially the soundtrack which is remarkable and very memorable. Finally, the game has a nice ammount of achievements and their cool names and fantastic icons make it particularly pleasing whenever one of them gets unlocked and pops up on the player's screen during the play.

I'm aiming to touch up on this text once I get the Special Edition DLC but I hope that even at its current state it's quite evident from my review that this game is a fantastic title and very much worth the buy.

reviewText:
This game was a real surprise for me, coming from both shank games to this is just pure amazing in gameplay and mechanics.

As far as stealth games goes, this to me is on par with the metal gear solid games, some mechanics even better than it. Being able to climb everywhere and how you can specifically kill guards in a variety of ways makes going through the game never makes it dull, really, terrorizing guards is the funnest thing you can do.

The vast amounts how you can approach a situation, depending on youre items, really feels good. The games doesnt penealize you for not killing people like most stealth games would.

I can say my only complaint is the game (on normal at least) is a bit too forgiving on you getting caught. The 8 second cooldown just feels like nothing, espcially when you can go right back to a guard that JUST saw you, then again getting caught does reduce your score greatly.

reviewText:
Mark of the Ninja is a stealth focused side scrolling 2.5D platforming game.  In it you play a Ninja on his quest to avenged his clan, then other stuff happens (sorry, spoilers if I said more)

Graphics: 9
Well done 2D graphics are timeless.  In 10 or 20 years we will look at this game and still say it looks good.

Sound: 8
Sound effects are spot on, if a bit repetitive.

Music: 5
Music is pretty basic but sets the mood nicely.  You won't be irritated by it, but you probably won't be searching for a sound track either.

Gameplay: 10
This is stealth done right.  You get all the tools you need to play exactly how you want.  You can run up to people and kick them in the face, you can hide and kill them quietly.  Or you can leave them to go back to their homes and wives and children and just sneak passed them.  The choice is yours.

Impression: 10
When you start the game, you will immediately be impressed with the scale of the game.  You will see many many paths you can take, and you will have many options on how to defeat the enemy or get passed them.  The game allows you to work as fast or as slow as you want.

Value:
This is a great game in the 10 dollar range and you will have lots of fun.

Summary:
If you love puzzles and stealth, you should get this game.

Note that although the game supports keyboard and mouse, it is difficult to use.  I suggest using an x-input controller instead.

reviewText:
Mark of the Ninja was a pleasant surprise that provided me with a great deal of entertainment for only a pittance (around $3). It stars a Ninja imbued with enchanted tattoos that give him special powers but also curse him with increasing madness, whose goal is to complete a mission of assassination and then take his own life before he loses the last remnants of his sanity.

The graphics and music are all appropriately ninja-themed which really helps to draw you into the overall atmosphere of the game. Most characters are fairly well animated for 2d and I was impressed by the level of effort put into the cinematics between levels (they had kind of a Samurai Jack vibe). The game also features helpful sound cues for when enemies are moving around in other rooms and for when you have been seen.

Since this is intended as a stealth game, gameplay consists of you finding your way through each level while avoiding detection and removing any obstacles, human or otherwise. Many of the areas had multiple routes that sometimes took me in completely different directions which I thought was a nice touch and added to overall replay-ability. Of course, it wouldn’t be a ninja game if you didn’t also have an array of ninja tools to deal with pesky enemies and inconvenient light sources. Besides your darts, you also have methods of distraction and extermination, and can customize your loadout at various points denoted by a hanging flag in each level. You will only have a few abilities at the start of the game, but you can unlock more by completing bonus challenges, finding secrets, and completing objectives.

The only gripe I have with Mark of the Ninja is that the controls can be a little quirky at times especially when moving between horizontal and vertical planes with contextual button commands. This wasn’t really a big deal but it did take me until near the end of the game before I finally got used to it. The game is also a bit short, but considering how cheap it is that’s not really a problem.

So, if you’re in the mood for a stealth-action ninja-themed game, try picking this one up. You might end up just as pleasantly surprised as I was!

reviewText:
I have seen tons of people recommend Mark of the Ninja, and now I know why. Mark of the Ninja is a great platformer and an even better stealth game! Mark of the Ninja has you playing a ninja warrior who has been given special powers by his clan, in order to avenge them, these powers however are slowly driving him mad. The game itself is done in a pretty unique art style for a stealth platformer, and its an art style I have found myself enjoying as I play.

Mechanically you are able to spring and grapple through the levels trying to remain out of sight of enemys. You can chose to try to complete the level without killing for a large bonus at the end, or you can massacre your way through the level building as many points as you can.  There are collectibles hidden levels as well, such as hidden challenge rooms, artifacts, and other secondary objectives you can collect to learn more of the lore.

The character is equipped with a variety of gear including a sword for executions and assassinations, firecrackers for distractions, throwing darts for distractions and interacting with items from a distance, and a few other items you will get throughout the game. This leaves the options open to play how you want, kill no one, kill a lot, or just stealth through like a ghost. The one takeaway from this is to NOT go in guns blazing, even when you do fight, keep it like a ninja.


Overall I would recommend Mark of the Ninja to fans of stealth games and paltformers, you have definitely got yourself a good game here!

reviewText: Easily one of the best Stealth games out there. Mark of the Ninja is one of the best games to come out in 2012. As a stealth game it's really well done, the idea that you're a ninja and not a samurai is a brilliant emphasis on the play style this game presents. As a Ninja your mission is to avenge your clan and take out the bad guys. Pretty simple in the story department. Gameplay is 2D and all the information you need to know is there, how much sound you make is given off by rings broadcasted from the last position you made noise, if enemies are with the radius of these rings then they'll investigate. The greatest thing is enemies suffer from fear, as you do horrible things to the unlucky schmucks they'll start panicking and this can go either way as they shoot their buddies or hit you in the process. Combat is pretty non-existent in this game. You can stun enemies, but you'll most likely be out-numbered and killed in that pursuit. Instead your attacks come in the form of gadgets, like traps. As long as an enemy cannot see you, you can kill in up-close stealth take-down form! The last point I want to make is masks. Masks alter the game in subtle ways that change how you approach sandboxes for example there is a mask that lets you take more Offensive gadgets or there is a mask that makes your enemies panic if they see corpses of their buddies anywhere (not just hanging from lamp-posts). The masks are all unlockable and this ties in with the game's replayability. The game is already highly replayable but the masks add different flavours of fun, and that's something the game is, amazing fun!

This game is easy enough to start playing, that many will find it entertaining.
As you progress, upgrades and more equipment are unlocked.
The game is simple but very fun to play.
You can choose two paths while playing each level. Either stealth or bloodbath/terror.
Terrorizing  guards is one of the most intresting elements in this game. Sometimes its enough killing one guard, and hang the body in the ceeling. Making several other guards go nuts and start fire wild in random directions. Also killing other guards.
The DLC is an intresting twist that also unlocks some more equipment for the main stoy. Its not that expensive and also get my thumb up. I recommend that if you have managed to clear the 5 first levels, buy the DLC for some more equipment. Some of it is quite helpful at that stage.

This game is incredible! I normally avoid stealth games, but after hearing all the hype about this one, I had to check it out. I'm glad I did! It has become one of my favorite games and will be one of the few that I will play back through from start to finish. This game was truly unique in a fantastic way and I am excited to see what comes next!
Absolutely fantastic game, definitely worth a purchase! Beautiful visuals with a nice story to boot. Gameplay is challenging and fun. If you are thinking of buying it just go ahead!
nice game.must try it

TL;DR - Mark of the Ninja provides good 6-7 hours of gameplay for the average player. If you don't totally suck and you don't score-attack, you're in for a few hours of stealth-action platforming and a fairly good storyline. If you're not into score-attacking and perfecting the game, or if you don't like stealth-focused games AT ALL, you might want to either wait for a sale or give it up completely; being careless and going for the extreme offensive won't get you very far in the game, and a good score unlocks quite a lot of stuff you can use to your advantage. I'm bad at stealth-based games, and I still had great fun with it. Awesome experience, will probably replay it sometime in the future.

Visuals: 7/10 MotN's graphics are very cartoony, and very similar to those which Klei showed us in its Shank games. While I'm not a huge fan of cartoon-ish graphics in video games, I do like the way information is conveyed through graphical cues and not in a form of text as it would in most other games.
For example, being a stealth-based game, Mark of the Ninja lets you know when you can't be seen/detected by draining the color from your character when he's in the darkness and outlining him in white, as opposed to showing the true color while standing in front of/under a source of light. Another example is being able to see the sound-waves coming from their source in a form of ripples, and seeing them in advance when aiming your equipment and tools (which allows for better stealth action and setting traps unheard and undisturbed).

Controls and UI: 8/10 Mark of the Ninja has fully rebindable keys and fully functioning menus in general. Controlling the equipment-selection menu with the mouse was a bit weird, but other than that it's alright.
WASD and Space (jump) to move, Left-click to attack and perform executions, Right-click to use the grappling-hook, E to interact with objects and Left-ctrl to stop time and use equipment.
The UI consists of the score-bar and the stealth-meter on the top left corner, and your equipment selection on the bottom left corner. Great controls, decent UI, nothing too intrusive or bad about any of these. No complaints here.

Music and SFX: 7/10 Both the voice acting and the music in the cut-scenes are good, but I didn't notice the music much when I actually played. Sound-effects are great, and the game handles sound-cues in a very interesting manner. I elaborated a bit about that in the Visuals section and I have nothing to add. No complaints here either.

Mechanics: 9/10 While there's no randomness involved in the levels and exploration is somewhat limited, they all provide at least two different ways to beat them. You gain more points by avoiding guards or killing them without being spotted, rather than going on a rampage and fighting them without any attempts to conceal yourself. This style-point system makes MotN especially fun for score-attackers and people who like to beat levels with the best score possible.
If you get close enough to your enemy without being noticed, you have an option to execute them - a QTE followed by an animation and the instant death of that foe. If you fail the QTE you will gain less points, and any nearby enemies will be alerted. You can unlock executions from the provided execution-tree to kill guards with less effort and in more convenient ways. In order to unlock them, and also new equipment, seal-points are required. You get these by completing side-missions (which are optional) and finding scrolls that are hidden in each level. Your score is calculated by the following factors: scrolls found and collected, side-missions done, and stars for your overall score. Gain overall-score by killing or disabling guards, by collecting artifacts (hidden as well) and by finding scrolls (1,000 points for each).

Replayability: 7/10 You can unlock new characters by completing side-missions and beating the game itself to then go back and play with said characters on previous levels (if you had a hard time perfecting them with the default one). The score and style-point based system, combined with the different characters and the many ways to complete levels, encouraged me to play through them more than once and try to beat them in the best way possible.
In general, you probably won't go through the whole story AGAIN, unless you want to try the New Game+ mode, but you MIGHT want to replay a level a few times just to get the maximum amount of points out of it and find all the scrolls/artifacts it provides. If you're not a score-attacker but you do love the stealth aspect of the game, you'll probably buy MotN for the sole purpose of completing the story, effectively dropping the replayability-value to 2 or 3 out of 10.
In my case, I did try to find EVERYTHING and perfect ALL the levels, so I put nearly 27 hours into it. Other than that, I was basically done with it after 9. It's up to you to decide whether the money is worth it or not.

EDIT - 24/11/2014   Updated the review to match my review-template - added Visuals, Controls and UI, Music and SFX, Mechanics, and Replayability. Before the update, all the review contained were parts of the Mechanics and the Replayability sections, and the TL;DR bit. I decided to organize it, add what was missing, and match it to the review template that I will be using for future reviews on my profile.
EDIT - 07/01/2015   Moved the TL;DR bit to the top - I realize some people don't feel like reading the whole review and just want to read my conclusion about the game right away. Reading the TL;DR first will probably help understand my point faster.

reviewText:
From the developers of the Shank series,and Don't Starve,here comes Mark of the Ninja.With such a dark setting,and of course,ninjas,this game won me over instantly.The story starts slow but gets unexpectedly interesting after a while and keeps to it till the end.
The graphics are top notch,and the art style is beautiful.The combat is flawless and incredibly fun for a 2D game,just as you would expect from klei Entertainment.The terrify system is delicious and with the help of some fun gadgets and upgrades,you can make it a truly
chaotic experience...for the enemy.They also took an interesting approach with the stealth kills,one that suprisingly works.
Oh,and did i mention the game flows incredibly well with both keyboard and gamepad? Well it does.
The DLC also adds some awesome additions that improve your experience,plus a new mission.
With that said,i encourage you to go get the game whenever you can,be it full price,or sale.

Spectacular and innovative indie game with a unique stealth game mechanic designed for a 2D environment.  Its artistic setting and dark themes belie a post-cyberpunk atmosphere.

The optional DLC is a full-length campaign, stars a new ninja with his own fighting style; comes with optional commentary from the indie devs themselves.

Shadowrun: Dragonfall (Indie!), Strider, and Mark of the Ninja (Indie!) are my favorite games!  All highly recommended, 10/10!

Genre: 2D Side-scroller Stealth Game
Reccommendation: A must play for those who like the stealth genre.
Playtime: ~9 hours. More if you play the DLC mission and New Game Plus.
Rating: 9/10
Review:

A really nice, 2D side-scroller stealth game, focused on being a Ninja and completing objectives like infiltrating a facility or taking down a target, and so on.

People say the storyline is short, but I don't think it is. Atleast, it isn't short if you don't rush through the game, and you explore the areas carefully and play slowly. Good amount of hours of playtime. (about 9 hours, if you don't count the DLC mission and New Game Plus)

The gameplay is just great. Stealth is very well done and you can be creative, as you can develop your own playstyle.
You can sneak through everything, avoiding getting detected by anybody at the same time. Or you can sneak up on every enemy and kill them, while not getting discovered. Or you can use FEAR against your enemies, depriving them from noticing you properly, and making them hurt their own allies too. You can probably mix this all up if you like, it's all your choice.

The graphics are cool too, as it has a lot of effects for a 2D game.

Overral, I highly reccommend this game to anybody out there that likes stealth games, no matter if you prefer it to be 3D games. I doubted this game because it was 2D, but turns out it was completely worth it.

This game is so close to being the perfect stealth game, a truly great experience, if a little short, though it still is very replayable. The game just never seemed to run out of challenging new things, or new ways to go about your mission; there is a ton of variety and choice, and it never gets old. A great buy, even at full price.
The best stealth 2D game I have ever played

Probably the best 2D stealth platform game I've ever played. Great visual arts and excellent gameplay mechanics which is really easy to master thanks to the fluid controls. With no sweat you will be able to pull of really cool ninja moves and plan out coordinated strategies to take out enemies without breaking stealth. At the beginning you are fairly weak, but you will eventually get upgrades which will make you an unseen killing machine. There are many different ways to play, and before each mission you can choose your ninja path which gives completely unique abilities depending on your preferred game style. The story is also surprisingly good, and you get cool cutscenes after each mission. You will also have to solve a fair share of puzzles and a lot of these are well integrated into the level design.\n\nHowever I do wish the theme was centered more around Japan. Having the story centered around the Meiji Restoration would be the perfect setting for this game. Maybe an idea for the sequel? :)
Awesome 2 D Stealth Game .
Definitely an awesome stealth game, great animations and great gameplay mechanics. Would buy again A+++++++....lol
great game i recomend 100%
A fun stealth-action platformer with a well told story and good replayability.

Phantastic platform/puzzle/stealth game. There are different solutions to each problem (undetected killing, diversions, open fight, evading, instill fear, ...), and the maps are more or less open, there are different ways to reach your waypoints. This variety makes the game quite interesting. Together with upgradeable items, learnable skills, achievements, leaderboards etc I think this game is very replayable. I've had 15 hours of great fun on my first playthrough.

I hope there will be a sequel some day, and my only points of critique are that despite the different tactics the background story feels a little repetitive (find object X, kill person Y), and the (great) visual style feels a little monotonous after many hours of playing (too dark & gloomy). But those things didn't spoil the fun at all for me. Oh, and maybe the non-stealth fights could be a little more complex, but that's not the focus of the game.

Cons:

On Linux the fullscreen mode is broken for me on dual head setups. The game takes over both screens, making it impossible to use the secondary monitor for anything. Alt-Tab to get out of the game is not possible from the game, but you can open the steam overlay to make it possible.

Nice stealh-action platformer with plenty of interesting gameplay quirks.  Get it right and you're sneaking through a complex, evading, slipping past and jumping out on guards.  Taking them out, hiding the bodies, stringing them up to terrorise" the rest of the enemy
date: or just slipping past  within inches of them disabling the lights and dropping smoke or even just slipping inside a convenient box or behind a nearby vase.\n\nGoing all-out violence isn't rewarded but even fleeing when spotted can be a valid tactic if you can get out of sight well enough.  A nice vision and sound system to evade detection or provide distraction
recommended: and it all works quite well.\n\nReminds me quite a bit of Saboteur on the ZX Spectrum."

Ever played Vector? Mark of the Ninja re-creates those 2D platforming and stealth-parkour mechanics one hundred times better, combining storyline, technique and the gore factor into one fantastic title.
NINJA MAN IS DA MAN

This game is amazing. Fantastic art and sound, and most of all Klei's touch makes for a fantastic time of getting to know systems within the game and then attempting to solve the puzzle within what looks like a ninja killing simulator. Just remember: playthrough with the original character and get all the no-kill bonuses. Killing might be satisfying but the feeling of making it all the way through without a single kill is perfect.
Fun stealth game with a plot twist somewhere in the game.

Mark of the ninja is a simple side scroller with an insanely good Gameplay and brilliant story. In Gameplay you can choose to go stealthy and avoid enemies or go for a more direct approach with wicked assassination moves. The game has just one downside on which I can comment. It lacks innovation. Yes the game has an awesome story, fun GamePlay and you  will probably enjoy the game if you play it but it doesn’t bring anything new to the table. Everything you see in this game was done before and because of all I stated above the game is getting a 7/10.

At first glance i thought it was going to be a boring platformer, then when I bought it i found out that it has to be one  of the best stealth/platformer games i have ever played. This game is highly recommended!
Awesome Graphics. High replay value due to different approaches. Addictive. Controls are only almost perfect. Altogether a damn good Platformer.
Best stealth gameplay ever.

This was a fun stealth based platformer that actually holds the threads to a very interesting story.

Being a trained ninja means mystically sticking to darkness and silently skulking about.  This also is the basis of the game, no skilled point and click, instead it is a great example of a game that requires patience to execute the enemies of your clan.  You will find yourself stealthing through sewers, across city tops, and worming your way through vents as you evade the eyes and ears of your enemies and bring silent death upon them.  There are special puzzel levels hidden about but the difficulty was slightly wanting I found.

The story is that of a chosen ninja, one who bears the marks that only his clan knows of, hence the title of the game.  The marks will imbue you with power beyond any mortal, but there is a price to pay.  The legend tells of those that undergo the ink will do the will of the clan and then must turn their sword upon themselves or else bring ruin on their clan.  This story element really comes to fruition at the very end and was wonderfully put forward by the creators.  The story also comes alive with the fun and stylized are found through the game.

I would recomend the this game for those who have patience for stealth, and for everyone if it is on sale.

Pros: Excellent stealth system, solid mechanics, actually creates feelings of tension with lighting and sound.
Cons: Occasionally clunky mouse controls, story felt short.

Overall, an excellent game.

Amazing stealth/platformer sidescroller that you shouldn't pass up. Everybody loves ninjas, backstabbing armed guards and karate chopping dogs. This game can be challenging but very rewarding, also there is a decent amount of replayability. Definitely worth buying!
the story line is not that good...\nbut the gameplay is superb...\nworth to play...
This game features a very indepth stealth system and has a very accurate portrail of real world ninjas. Anyone who is a fan of stealth adventure games should get this title.

Best. Stealth. Ever. Sneaking past people is actually just as fun as killing them. (Well, ok, maybe just a teensy tiny little bit less fun than killing them). Only gripe - occasionally the stealth kill command feels a bit...clunky. It's simple enough, just not quite as smooth as everything else.
9.5/10. Will stealth the ♥♥♥♥ out of everyone again because new game plus. And now I have even more ways to kill things and sneak past things.

Almost everything in this game is perfect. Visuals and music, gameplay, storytelling, quests and challenges.

Everything matches together in a harmony that creates one of the most memorable atmospheres I've experienced lately.

The story itself isn't something special, at least on the surface of it. But the decision you have to take at the end is actually very challenging and could make you thing twice about how you interpret certain things.
Read this topic if you're interested [SPOILERS!] - http://steamcommunity.com/app/214560/discussions/0/864956554675429463/.

Also, the DLC adds some missing pieces to the puzzle.

Overall, I highly recommend the game.

This excellent stealth game from the creators of Shank offers non-linear levels and a plot that will keep you interested from beginning to end.  It is a must-play for any stealth fan, but the DLC is kinda meh.

This game is incredible! I normally avoid stealth games, but after hearing all the hype about this one, I had to check it out. I'm glad I did! It has become one of my favorite games and will be one of the few that I will play back through from start to finish. This game was truly unique in a fantastic way and I am excited to see what comes next!

Wow.  A rare stealth game!
Play as you want, be a dangerous assasin! Be a shadow that hides in the night! Be the Darkness itself!
Really atmospheric game, great on stealth, wonderful animations, original mechanics!
I definitely recommend!
I'll be honest, it was much better than I expected. I knew it was a good stealth game, but then they turn around and pistol-whip you with an amazing story.

-Great artstyle
-Fun Gameplay
-Good Story
-Ninja stealth

The only thing i didn't like was the controls or maybe i just suck, or maybe it is because i'm using a keyboard and a controller is recommended.

This game is great fun  9/10
Great game. Love playing it.
This game an interesting one. The unique art style combined with the stealth mechanics and the multiple options available will really test your mind on different strategies.
The best stealth game to date, not even mentioning that this is the best ninja game out there.\n\nCheers!

Only just played the first level, but this game already has me totally convinced of its ingenuity. Very smooth and nice gameplay mechanics. Intriguing storytelling also! Im all excited for what yet lies before me!

Excellent stealth game with quite a lot of replay value. Lovely art style. I played with an Xbox controller so can't speak for kb/mouse controls.

It's a 2D (with a hint of 3D) side-scrolling game, so performance is quite good. Solid 60 fps at 1080p with a GTX560.

The game's also got random philosophical angles to it which I had missed, initially.

Highly recommended.
An amazing stealth game, made very well. Keeps you thinking. Not easy. Good puzzles. If you like Assassins Creed, would you most likely love this game!

I could not have asked for a better ninja game. Everything about this game screams terrific design. It captures the spirit of true ninjutsu: complete nothingness and silence, alongside the occasional assassination. The path you take as a ninja is completely up to you, ranging from a murderous nightmare towards every guard to an undetectable ghost. The game is more than happy to give you various options in approaching every situation. I was also pleased by how varied the levels are; one time you will be infiltrating a fortress, the next time you'll be escaping poison-filled catacombs, and another time you will be setting a building on fire. I also found the game to be quite challenging and as of writing this review have yet to earn all the achievements...and complete a harder New Game+.
The art direction is fantastic, harkening me back to the style of Batman: The Animated Series, Star Wars: Clone Wars, and Samurai Jack. Plus, the visual cues regarding sound and light is nothing short of genius.
The story is surprisingly intriguing and the end led to much reflection of my playthrough as a ninja. The characters are good with well-executed voice-acting. Overall, very well-written.
With all this being said, this is a ninja game. What more could you want? 10/10
one of the best games i have ever played
This game blew my mind. One of the best Stealth Games I have ever played, and I play a LOT of stealth games.

With its beautiful art and flowing animations, this game not only looks amazing but plays amazing. Its also the best stealth game I've played, with many options, playstyles, and paths. Unlockables, extras, collectables, and a new game+ mode keep the game fun if you want to play it again. One of the best games I've ever played.
this game equals will shatner's scrotum

Mark of the Ninja is a wonderful stealth based game with a surprisingly well thought out story. As far as 2-D stealth platformer games go, Mark of the Ninja is definitely the king. The player must use a veriety of tools along with the environment to either kill the gaurds, or sneak past them. The player is heavily rewarded with staying out of combat, and remaining undetected which proposes a unique challange to each player. The points the player receive will also help them upgrade their arsonal and allow them to complete each level more easily; which is good, because as the game progresses the levels become increasingly difficult. If you're looking for a challenging stealth and puzzel type game, look no further.

Mark of the Ninja is one of the best stealth games that I've ever played.

The 2D layout, various execution methods, plentiful items, soundtrack, and art take this game to the top. There are different paths that you can choose throughout the game and you can pick one according to your playstyle. Whether you want to sneak around guards and be non-lethal or if you want to create the largest bloodbath the world has ever seen, the possibles for you are endless in this stealth game.

The way that vision is handled is very precise and clean. Vision tends to make or break stealth games but this one does it incredibly well.

The achievements aren't too hard to get either if you're a hunter.

Great game that proves that 2D is not dead and is an overall better choice for stealth and platforming. Enjoyable from beginning to end, quite diverse in the approaches to a level, tight controls (with a X360 controller). Must buy!

Excellent 'stealth' style game.  You're a ninja who must accomplish different tasks that require you to be stealthy and deadly.  You're given ninja tools and weapons to accomplish your given tasks with scenarios that allow for a range of different kills or kill styles with a range of bonus points for either.

The gameplay is smooth and your ninja is easy to control whether you're using the keyboard/mouse or a gamepad (360 controller).  The game puts a nice twist on the 'stealth' genre of games by including more than a stay out of the lights" playing mentality you usually find.  Of course you have to stay out of the lights but the game makes you think without getting overly complex in movement controls or in problem solving.  I became quite comfortable with movement and action controls rather quickly.

Each level has a number of challenges that contribute to your ranking at the end of that level (IE: hitting all the gongs will get you a bonus).  This allows you to farm for achievements within the game level as well as the Steam achievements for the game itself.

If you're into 'stealth' style games
date: this one's a 'must have'.  If you haven't tried 'stealth' style games
recommended: this is a nice place to start. Buy it on sale."

reviewText: I love this game. It's a 2D platforming stealth game, but the controlls are tight, and it's very rewarding. It's a lot of fun dispatching the enemies in fun and unique ways and each level provides different paths you can take through it. It's a pretty good length for the price, about 10 hours on a single playthrough, and the different item/upgrade system lets you play each level how you prefer. Probably the best stealth game I've played next to splinter cell chaos theory.

The purest, most effective stealth experience available, in a novel 2D environment. This game perfectly pitches character progression and challenge, marrying atmosphere and threat with power-fantasy.\n\nIt's in actuality a puzzle game; if you are detected and discovered, the punishment is rarely less than swift death and a fast reload. Perhaps punishment is the wrong word, as the game never penalises you for failing to outwit one of it's systems, but challenges you to do so with all the timing, strategy and grace of a true ninja. This approach to stealth is something many other titles avoid, especially AAA games with long loading times, which give players to option of fighting their way out of their mistakes. While this may avoid frustrating players with constant failure, 'Mark of the Ninja' proves that less is more when it comes to the mastery of stealth.
absolutely brilliant stealth game. Gorgeous visuals. Great replayability and there's a choice at the end for the story you had too much fun playing to worry about. stop reading, play this game.

The graphics are top notch,and the art style is beautiful.The combat is flawless and incredibly fun for a 2D game,just as you would expect from klei Entertainment.The terrify system is delicious and with the help of some fun gadgets and upgrades,you can make it a truly
chaotic experience...for the enemy.They also took an interesting approach with the stealth kills,one that suprisingly works.
Oh,and did i mention the game flows incredibly well with both keyboard and gamepad? Well it does.
The DLC also adds some awesome additions that improve your experience,plus a new mission.
With that said,i encourage you to go get the game whenever you can,be it full price,or sale.

A stylized 2D take on the stealth genre. Overlooked this game for a while but really glad I picked it up. The game has a decent sized campaign with lots of challenges in every level. I found there was a lot of ways to approach every situation, either with lethal or non lethal takedowns, entry points or use of gadgets. Really felt like a true badass ninja in this game. You have the ability to terrorize your enemies and sink back into the shadows, causing them to panic and attack other guards, it's pretty great. I felt like Batman. Like I said very nicely stylized, which I expected from a Klei game. Nice art direction and animations all around, and cool tradition ninja themes mixed with more high-tech stuff. Still think I'm going to play this more to complete more challenges and play with different loadouts and ninja suits. If you're into stealth or sidescrollers I'd say pick this up!

This is one of the few stealth games I've played that doesn't have frustration spikes. The game rewards you for not being detected, but it is lax enough, so it doesn't get counted as soon as someone sees you. Drawing the enemies can be used to alter the situation to your benefit. The game also rewards you for either killing everyone or not killing anyone, since you get a bonus for not killing anyone. Anyways, there are a lot of good and interesting things this game brings to the stealth game genre that I haven't noted here, and I encourage anyone who likes the genre to get this game.

Overall, I highly recommend the game.

Your Ninja-clan is under threat by a mysterious mercenary-group and you are chosen to protect it. For that, you are given the Mark of the Ninja, a set of rad tattoos which increase your abilities tenfold at the cost of your mind. Over time, the Mark drives the bearer insane and he must kill himself.
The way towards your inevitable fate is to be littered with corpses, though, as you seek to find out what the attack was all about. Mark of the Ninja is a 2D sidescrolling game in which, generally spoken, your goal is to get from the left end to the right end of each level. This is, of course, not all, as various bonus-objectives and collectibles are scattered throughout each mission. Unlike pretenders like (modern) Splinter Cell or even Thief, MotN definitely focuses on stealth above all. Enemies have guns, you have an array of ninjaesque weapons like a sword, kunai (throwing daggers) and a grappling hook. These put you at a disadvantage when going up against the mercenaries directly, so you should stick to the shadows at all times. Making use of the environment to either kill or avoid enemies is what makes up the largest portion of this game. Deciding which route to take, how to take care of them one by one without being spotted etc.. You can use ventilation-shafts and high-up ledges to help you get around. While taking care not to be SEEN, being HEARD is also a threat. Sprinting will give you away to those close by, as will using your grappling hook. The game offers very clear indications, showing you whether or not you can be seen and how far the sound you make will travel, which you can use to your advantage to lure people around as you please.
Collecting XP from your kills and secrets will allow you to level up your abilities between levels, as well as give you more different kill-moves.
While it is possible to play this game with a keyboard only, using a controller of your choice (preferrably an XBox one for USB) will make the game a lot more fluent and easier to control. Be warned: There are some quick-time-events involved.
Mark of the Ninja has some very pretty 2D graphics which feel absolutely in place for a game like this. It makes for an easy to pick up distraction when you just cannot find the time to play something large". I picked this up during the last sale
recommended: it is not very expensive.\nHave a controller handy? Grab this gem!"

This game is great and am really enjoying it.  It is overall very well made:  comic book-esque animation beautifully done including animated cut scenes; voice acting is very quality; controls with a Playstation (and I assume Xbox) are very good and fit perfectly with the gameplay, which also very excellent and fun (I have not tried playing with a keyboard and/or mouse).  I am also enjoying the plot so far.

The best way I can inadequetely describe the game is a wonderful side scrolling combination of Tenchu and stealth/predator aspects of the recent Batman Arkham games that is completely unique in its own way and doesn't feel derivitive of either.

My only minor quibble is that I wish there were more variation in the stealth kills, both requiring more variety in skill/button combinations to execute as well as more variety in execution moves/deaths, though I am not very far in the game and these may have already been implemented, just haven't gotten there yet.

I got this on sale, but I would have been fine if I had paid the full price (which is currently $14.99), and I highly recommend this game to anyone whom finds the above description appealing.

When I first played this game, I was frustrated by the difficulty level.Controls can be difficult sometimes on pc, but you get used to them after a while. There is a learning curve and the first levels aren't as well designed as the ones later in the game. However, when you get used to the controls and the stealth mechanism (which is superb!), this game transforms into probably the greatest stealth game I ever played. The story (especially the ending) is beautifully executed and can have subtle plot twists at times. This game is even more fun when played a second time, after you get used to the gameplay and having experienced the story. You will notice the easter eggs in the story and play like a true ninja.

Phantastic platform/puzzle/stealth game. There are different solutions to each problem (undetected killing, diversions, open fight, evading, instill fear, ...), and the maps are more or less open, there are different ways to reach your waypoints. This variety makes the game quite interesting. Together with upgradeable items, learnable skills, achievements, leaderboards etc I think this game is very replayable. I've had 15 hours of great fun on my first playthrough.

I hope there will be a sequel some day, and my only points of critique are that despite the different tactics the background story feels a little repetitive (find object X, kill person Y), and the (great) visual style feels a little monotonous after many hours of playing (too dark & gloomy). But those things didn't spoil the fun at all for me. Oh, and maybe the non-stealth fights could be a little more complex, but that's not the focus of the game.

Cons:

On Linux the fullscreen mode is broken for me on dual head setups. The game takes over both screens, making it impossible to use the secondary monitor for anything. Alt-Tab to get out of the game is not possible from the game, but you can open the steam overlay to make it possible.

If you were to only play one platformer [or a stealth game] this year, let it be this one. Amazingly fun, excellent level design, only as many unlockable skills as you can actually use and - a good story. [Yes, really.]\n\nA gamepad is recommended.

I recently reviewed this game for my game review blog, Five Penny Review. If you enjoy this review, please visit my page:
http://fivepennyreview.blogspot.com/2013/08/mark-of-ninja.html

What sets this game apart?
While I have certainly played first-person shooter games that had some reliance on stealth, I have never played many games that would be considered a part of the stealth genre.  The idea of a stealth game designed as a 2D platformer intrigued me, so I tried Mark of the Ninja during the Steam sale and was not disappointed.  While many stealth games seem to devolve into combat at some point, it is fully optional in Mark of the Ninja, and its system is highly tuned to allow you to emphasize stealth and movement.  If you are the type that prefers killing everything in sight, you can still functionally play the game as long as you do so carefully.  The art style is creative and complements the story well, and the cut scenes are generally well composed.

What is the difficulty factor?
While this game does a good job of pausing to offer instruction when new mechanics are introduced, the controls for the PC version are not discussed and can be a bit challenging as a result.  Once you experiment enough to figure out how everything works, the mouse control actually makes your movement and aim very natural.  Mark of the Ninja is a fairly difficult game as you progress, largely because of how unforgiving it can be.  It does not take much to kill you if you get caught, and if the alarm sounds it causes a huge loss of points that make it difficult to complete all of the tasks for the level.  With that said, the game is also as hard as you make it, as maximizing your points, completing side missions, and collecting all of the hidden scrolls are all completely optional.  When you do complete the game, the New Game + mode offers an entirely new level of difficulty, even less forgiving and relying much more on your ability to be aware of your surroundings and react quickly.

Does it use media effectively?
The art style utilized by the game is strange, but highly effective.  The game uses smooth cartoonish animation that complements both the style and story, especially considering the story elements involving scrolls and tattoos and the connections in the art style.  The voice acting and music are good enough, but nothing spectacular, especially with the often mediocre dialogue.  The place where this game really shines, however, is in the mechanical visuals and subtle sounds.  The game represents sounds with a ripple effect, revealing when enemies make noise near you and letting you know how far the sounds you make reach, and shows the visual range of enemies with a simple cone before them.  The use of subtle sounds such as footsteps, light switches, doors, and vents play an equally important role, especially in the New Game + mode where the sound ripples no longer appear.

Best moment in the game?
While the cut scenes have their good moments, the gameplay is really where this game shines.  As you unlock new styles, there are some really neat effects in the gameplay, and for me the most interesting is the Path of Nightmares.  In this mode, it becomes easier to trigger the “terrorized” condition in enemies, resulting in the enemies randomly shooting at any little noise, or running and screaming.  This adds another element to the game, as you discover creative ways to terrify the enemies.

Who needs to play this game?
Mark of the Ninja can be played in a variety of ways and can appeal to a variety of different players.  Players who enjoy stealth games like the Tenchu series will likely enjoy it.  Players who enjoy classic platformers will get a lot of enjoyment out of the puzzle-platforming sections, especially the catacombs.  The New Game + mode is extremely challenging, while playing the standard game without going for a high score can be fun to just play around.  It is available on Xbox Live and Steam.

Mark of the Ninja is a game you should buy.
If you like sneaky games this is definitely for you. It’s one of the best ninja-sneaky-backstab games I have ever played and the sheer intelligence and commitment of the devteam to create a great experience for the player is admirable.

It took me maybe 14-17 hours for my first playthrough (guessing), and the rest of the time (of a total 26,6h) to play the new DLC level, playing it through again in NG+ and collecting all achievements.

In short it’s a platform sneak game, you play as a ninja with various skills, keeping to the shadows and trying to advance by backstabbing or avoiding the enemies. You are not the strongest fighter and while you can fight one-on-one, you won’t survive multiple alert enemies, so you take it slow and plan your way forward.

However, if things go south you can always flee, or just reload, often you have a checkpoint just outside the area that you tried to clear, so you can be back where you was in a matter of seconds. The game load saves instantly, I have reloaded some checkpoints probably 10-15 times over and over just because I haven’t gotten the right outcome.

So, the game is great, the areas present different challenges with both puzzles and enemy encounters, forcing you to become a better ninja.

Gameplay and design is top-notch, they have put a lot of time in everything from how you make sound to how the enemies walk, act and react. You see enemy sightcones, if they have nightvision, what status they are in and when you run what soundwaves that you make, giving you optimal information to how to approach any situation.

Through a time-stop mode you can queue up several actions that will be performed by the ninja. So while you are jumping off from a light you can stop time and throw two darts and a poisonbomb and then grapple away to a treebranch.

You have optional suits to change up your gameplay, I enjoyed almost all of these in my NG+ playthrough, some giving you hilarious combos and chain effects that makes you squeal happily in your seat.

NG+ makes the game harder by removing most of the help that you get as a player, after having played the normal mode and learning these things by heart, it’s very thrilling to not see what’s behind your character. Having to guesstimate how close you can run up to an enemy before he notice your footsteps, or how close you can get to the dog without it picking up your trail. Going by enemy design to judge if they have night-vision and if they are looking in your direction. I enjoyed NG+ maybe even more than normal mode, but the normal mode was excellent practice for it, if I hadn’t played the game in normal mode first, I probably wouldn’t have liked NG+.


So, bad stuff, honestly it’s not that much. Controls can act up a bit, they can be kind of finicky where you need to look to get the correct action. When it’s a tight space and you slide down just behind an enemy you miss some actions that would seem natural to do.
Some checkpoints in the later levels are horrendous, especially in the last level where you can spawn inside a house where there is a very dangerous enemy patrolling, whom you don’t want to get seen by. Some areas are very large, making a small mistake cost you a lot of work. But most of the time it just work and feels natural.
I’ve probably become annoyed by more things but honestly they are a speck of dust on a gem.


Graphics pretty much look like a very, very pretty flashgame, same with the cinematics. Don’t look down on this, it looks awesome and the ninja animations are awesome. A lot of work have gone into the style to make surfaces and the areas both pretty and functional.

Music is mostly ambient, works well but nothing you will write love poems about.

Technically it worked fine, I played with a Xbox 360 controller and had no crashes or anything mess my game up.

Hope you buy it and enjoy it as much as I did! :D

Mark of the Ninja is one of the best stealth games, one of the best platformers, and one of the best ninja games in recent years.  With a gameplay style that rewards tactical precision while still keeping a brisk pace, the game manages to work your brain and reflexes in a way that feels exciting and familiar as a player.\nThe story is clichéd but sincere, the levels are more videogame than reality, and sometimes you'll encounter a loophole or exploit to take away your immersion in favor of ratcheting up your score, but you'll enjoy every minute of it.  Every challenge is met with enjoyment.  No part of the game ever feels like it drags or has that boring act" structure.\nThe gameplay is finely tuned
date: with inspiration from every major stealth title out there put to good use.  Nothing is wasted; everything is fun.  There's little higher praise than that.\n\nAnd it has the best type of New Game + mode
recommended: where the fundamental mechanics are altered significantly for a heightened challenge."

Mark of the Ninja is a slick and stylish stealth action platformer.

You infiltrate and assassinate your way through 12 gorgeously designed levels. The art is beautiful and the animations are slick. There is a range of environments, each with stunning vibrant parallax scrolling backgrounds offsetting the generally monochrome foreground.

You start out with a relatively simple set of moves, introducing you to how stealth works in the game; Enemies have vision cones, moving quickly makes sound which draws enemies, you can hide behind environmental objects like vases and dumpsters, slipping through vents and setting up ambushes.

The game slowly increases your equipment and move set (all of which can be customised) as you play. Each level has challenges for you to attempt, each of which unlocks a token you can spend on upgrading your gear. Complete enough of certain challenge types will unlock new costumes which include a gear restriction or boon. For example, completing 3 'Terror' challenges unlocks a gear set that makes you run without making any noise, but you lose your sword, forcing you to a fast and non-lethal playstyle.

The story is relatively simplistic, but presented in short stylized cutscenes that work well. The story has a twist with a choice at the end, but it is nothing earth-shattering and not really the focus of the experience. The joy here is in the gameplay, the smooth controls (even if playing with a keyboard and mouse) and the art.

After completion you unlock a new game plus mode, which increases the number of guards and increases the difficulty.

2D stealth game that has managed to balance the difficulty curve across nearly 12 full levels. Extremely replayable with leaderboards as well as many side objectives and collectibles hidden in the darkness of your player's surroundings.

A thinking man's game that's also insanely fun to play, Mark Of The Ninja is stealth perfected on a 2D plane. There are numerous ways to approach any given situation: use darts to create distractions that help you navigate your way undetected past guards, lure enemies into traps you set, dangle above them and string them up Batman-style, hide in a vent below and pull them under or let them pass...whether you choose to go full stealth and avoid everyone or to murder all the bad guys on screen, the game rewards you, which is refreshing given that most stealth games penalize you for taking the latter route despite how much fun it is. Your enemy's field of vision is represented as a Metal Gear Solid-style cone and the audible noises you make as expanding & contracting circles - this results in the near-complete absence of a HUD, which further immerses you in the game's superb Sumi-E art design as the difficulty rises on a steady incline, never failing to challenge you in new and creative ways. Mark Of The Ninja stylishly takes its place among the best of its kind and deserves every bit of the acclaim it's garnered.

reviewText:
Mark of the Ninja can be described thusly

Stealthy murder fun - ambiguity

or SMF - ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t if you're feeling visceral

Basically, this is pretty much exactly how a stealth based game should work, giving you clear visual feedback on how everything relates and letting you solve problems however you see fit.  Naturally, the best solution to a problem usually involves removing that problem but you are rewarded for ghosting through and leaving everyone alive and unaware you were ever there.  The rewards come in the form of even more ways to murder people though, so that's... conflicted I guess.

This dualistic nature also extends into the visuals which favor about as bright and expressive a style as one could really have in a game about sticking to the darkness.  This pays off with really satisfying expressions on your victims during kills for the more sadistic among you but it will definitely bother those who want their grindhouse ninja-ing to be taken as seriously as the central storyline suggests.

Oh, and if you hate halfway sitting games, you WILL be murdered toot sweet if you decide to just charge in and attack head on.  Just thought you should know that if you have the patience of a sugared up teen.

Well worth the price, and if you get it on sale, even better.

There's a great amount of replayability thanks to each level's goals, the extra unlockables, and the more difficult story mode replay which is unlocked after beating the main story. Here's the gist of it: you're a ninja. End of explanation.

Of course, that isn't helpful at all for a review, so let me start over. In Mark of the Ninja (MotN) you play the role of a ninja that just received a tattoo (hence, the Mark of the Ninja) and wake up to hearing the ninja complex you live in under attack. I won't go any further on the story since I do think it would ruin everything for everyone.

The biggest truth to be said about this game is that it is a stealth-approach game. Before it, you can argue that the stealth genre was lacking some sort of depth. You can also argue that Metal Gear games want you to use stealth, but in no way does Snake compete with the protagonist of MotN.

As a ninja, you get your standard ninja stereotypes. If you're sneaky, you are lethal and kill anything that isn't a rock in one precise assassination strike. Resorting to fighting out in the open = you died, because if you've seen Indiana Jones you know that gun beats any weapon skill as long as there is any range between two persons, and that's when there's only one gunman. Throwing knives are infinite, but cheap as they are they can't kill people: only force them to go look for the wise guy that thought of jabbing them with glorified sharper sticks.

So, naturally, you need some ninja gear that actually does stuff. Well, say no more. Spike traps that make witnesses of their workings lose their mind over how gory they can get? Check. Smoke bombs to create visibility problems and let you move with no fear? Check. Beetles to eat your enemies and leave no evidence...? Wow, I wouldn't want to be the one handling that particular jar. Bottom line is that there are plenty of tools for your ninja. But also bottom line, fine print, is that you are restricted severely as to how many of said devices you can carry, and even of the types of devices you can carry.

Because you see, being a ninja is cool and all, but you can be a specialist in the world of the ninjas too. Unlock different suits and get something improved, at the cost of gimping something else. For some people it may be that they want to guarantee not to screw up an assassination, or that their bare fists actually hurt people, or that they want to be able to teleport around because you know that's going to save your life for sure. It all boils down to how you play the game that will have you choose which outfit is the best fit for you.

I've been saying good things about the game. Are there any bad things about the game? Yes.

The story feels short. A good player on his first run might unlock just about everything at the first opportunity provided. Other than the imposed limitations of the system and how creative you are, some sections are not exactly very interesting or are unjustifiably difficult for almost no reason. The hard mode" is basically the exact same game
date: except you die with a single hit (as you should
hoursPlayed: ) and you lose your fourth wall of indicators (sounds happening and visual fields) of the environment
voteText:
which you also shouldn't be playing with them on unless you're learning how far each goes.

And there. That's it. That's the review of the game. Now let me review something else.

reviewText:
Pretty good game.  I enjoyed it a lot.

I especially liked how clear the stealth elements were.  You always know exactly how much noise you'll make and who will hear it, and you also always have a strong idea of how well and where the enemy can see.  Good times.

The stages are long, however, and if you intend to kill all the dudes/do all the things expect to take about 30-50 minutes per level.  I had difficulty playing more than one stage at a time and I very often got kind of bored about halfway into a stage.  As fun as the game is, it gets very monotonous: there really isn't a whole lot of variety going on here.

The music and sounds are pretty solid but the voice acting is lacking (much like it was in Shank, whatcha gon' do).  The story, while basic, is good and I liked it.

There's an upgrade system but there might as well not be for how much it comes into play.  You'll grab the super useful things, like the ability to kill dudes from behind doors or in cover, almost right away and then just not really want anything else.  Nothing is bad, necessarily, but a lot of the abilities just aren't really useful.  Additionally, by completing x number of different objective types (terror, stealth, kill things and maybe a few others) you unlock different suits.  The different suits change the basic gameplay somewhat, such as allowing you to carry two attack items instead of an attack and distraction item.  The different skillsets are neat but I never really found myself wanting to use anything aside from the basic set because it's so balanced.

The first playthrough isn't so difficult but when you do make mistakes you usually won't have to repeat large chunks of the stage.

I got about 8-10 hours of play out of this, which was about double the time I spent on Shank, so that's good.  Additionally I wasn't so big on gathering all the hidden stuff or acing all of the stages, and I also didn't do NG+, so there's a lot of potential for this game to eat up a lot of time (assuming that's what you're into).

Overall I considered this a very positive and enlightening experience.  If nothing else, it had me thinking about platformers and general stealth elements differently than I had in the past, and that's great (from a design perspective, at least).  It's a good game and it should definitely be in your library.
Despite it's 2d appearance it's a really great stealth game, up there with thief and dishonored.

What is it? Play it and find out.

reviewText: Excelente juego de plataformas y stealth en 2D. La historia es interesante y eso es a pesar de un final tan copado como predecible. Lo realmente copado son los puzzles logicos y el constante foco en el sigilio, todo el tema de ser detectado y esconder los cuerpos esta copado también. Me gusto mucho mas de lo que pensaba y luego que le hinque el diente, se me dificulto pila soltar el gamepad. Definitivamente recomendado.

Really enjoyable game. Considering the price of this title (which would be worth the money at full price, but I was lucky enough to get this during a sale at 75% off) I am thoroughly impressed and have seen alot less effort and polish on so called big titles priced at £30/£40. Very addictive, great looking and well thought out stealth game that I would recommend to anyone looking to pick up a bargain and something abit different.

I haven't played too much stealth games in the many year's of gaming but offhand I have to say that this is a pretty sweet deal. Those who are fans of classic side scroll games should get this one as it makes for a good break from all the usual mechanics of the platform.

The shadowy business you get into in this games is presented quite well. The art style was the first thing that got me hooked - this game is the bloodier, darker, more violent cousin of Samurai Jack. Set in a modern day metropolis, the environment makes for a good contrast to the ancient arts of the ninja. The ancient ways will be challenged by all modern means - guns, spotlights, motion sensors, and laser triggered security.

The shadowy arts never felt any simpler with the smoothness of controls - there is little room for the awkward movements and bad camera angles in this 2D platformer. Slipping in and out of the shadows is one click away! This, I think, is another good score for the game as it leaves only your good timing and judgement to deal with a present challenge.

Levels have varied goals to meet - the game can't be done perfectly by just staying hidden in the shadows forever. There are instances where your blade will get stained. (In some occasions, the goals aren't even related to being a ninja but it's all fun and challenging all the same.)

As you progress into the game, your are introduced to its very own customization system. Clearing goals allow you to buy additional stealth kills and improved ninja styles and tools.

The story - which I haven't finished, actually, isn't really that unique. Revenge and self-preservation is its very core to say the least, cloaked in shadow and with a very sharp sword.

For those who are fans of side-scrolling and stealth, this one should definitely not be missed.

I thought I had played the ultimate stealth game by the time I had finished Gunpoint and I shouldn't say I have been proven wrong but I haven't been proven right either. Mark of the Ninja is a terrific stealth game in which only your creativity and some slightly rough game mechanics are the limits. You take on the role as a ninja of the Hisomu clan nad set out on a mission to avenge your fallen comrades after a raid on your clan's home.
The game offers a rich amount of tools that you can use as you progress through the various missions. Your items include a sword, darts, a grappling hook, various items used for distraction and some used for trap kills.
You can choose to kill every enemy alive or go unseen through the whole game but no matter what your moral choices are, you'll hopefully find yourself striving towards some very addictive additional goals during the playthrough.

Of course, the game isn't perfect and that should be noted. I never enjoyed the art style a lot. That is because it felt rather American, while the game revolves around japanese characters. Some of the mechanics are slightly buggy and that can be bothersome until you find your way around it. The last enemies in the game just feel rather cheap and overpowered. One annoyance is that there are some achievements that you can only unlock if you have the DLC, which feels like a cheap way to make users purchase it just to beat the game 100%.

I got this game as a part of a Humble Bundle, and thought 'Oh, looks interesting, Ill probably play it for a while, then NEVER touch it again.' How wrong I was. Mark of the Ninja is a strong showing, reminding us all that there will always be life in Indie Games.

Buy. This. Game.

Okay, to explain. This game is the best and will surely stay the best 2d stealth game I have EVER played for years to come.
The art style is amazing, the animations are stunnning, the stealth is solid, the gameplay is smooth, and the controls are tight, at least with a controller.

The Topics

Controls - When using an X-Box controller, the controls are just beautiful. I cannot speak for the keyboard controls as I do not use them, but I am sure they are at least decent.
Aesthetics - I could go on forever here, but I can say that both the art and animations are awesome.
Enviroment - The atmosphere is great, and the settings are somewhat believeable.
Story - Cannot say much without spoiling, but it is much better then you would expect from a 2d game with a score system.
Performance - Great, I have a fairly old dual core computer and it run this game fine.
Replayability - I have not replayed this game much, but I can assure you that you could replay this plenty.
Price - The price is quite acceptable, in my opinion many AAA games asking for 60 dollars are worse.
Length Pretty good for a game of this price, plus the replayability bumps it up.

My verdict:

10/10 Would sneak again

Made by the same developers, this greatly less brutal stealth-action inherits the flawless visual style of Shank. And raises it to the absolutely new level. What about gameplay? Nothing special, just a best stealth of the year. Dishonored? Hitman? Blah...

My first impression of this game was a quick little stealth title to hold me over for an hour or two. Little did I know that I would have eventually put in nearly 30 hours of quality gaming into this artistic masterpiece.

Right off the bat I could tell how polished and clean the graphics were. What really made the game sing were the simple lighting effects and the amazing depth of field they added. Depth of field in a 2D game! Who would've thought. Basically, whatever isn't in your character's line of sight is blurry. Simple yet added a nice touch to the game. The running, killing, climbing, etc animations were all fluid and sexy. Nice simple cinematics added to the feel of the game.

So it looks great, and sounds just as good. I love the ambiance in the game. The drums are my favorite, really sets the pace of the game. Audio is nice and smooth, nothing sounded off while playing.

The gameplay itself was something unexpected. It started off simple, and got more complex as it continued. I had no problems finishing the levels while either killing everyone or not killing anyone. Most levels had several paths and ways to handle every situation. Even more so, with the array of tools you're provided to handle missions. I honestly never came to a part of the game that frustrated me, or made me want to rage quit. With each obstacle presented, I had fun figuring out the best way to handle each situation.

Mark of the Ninja is going on my top list of favorite games. It's well worth the $15 asking price, regardless of any kind of steam sale. Crossing my fingers for a sequel.

*INITIAL IMPRESSIONS*\nI'll be the first one to admit, I don't have much of a mind for stealth games (Dishonored being the only stealth game I well and truly enjoyed), Mark of the Ninja is a hardcore stealth title. There is no actual combat, meaning if the player is spotted then you have to run, hide and accept the penalty to your final score.\nI like the concept of sticking to the shadows and utilizing the environment to move from point to point to avoid being seen, the player can climb to higher areas, hide in vents, duck behind cover or create a distraction to keep out of the sightlines of the patrolling guards. What I dislike about MotN is how the kills are managed, utilizing one of my greatest gaming pet-peeves, quick-time events. When you approach an enemy and click on them to begin your attack, the game will give you a split-second warning to slide your mouse either to the left or the right, a successful attempt will give you a silent assassination while failure to complete the event will end up making a lot of noise and attracting nearby guards. (This is especially bad if you're like me and you can never immediately figure out left from right on the spot. Don't you DARE judge me).

I don't remember the last time I was so taken by a 2D game. But by this I sure was, maybe it's even the best 2D game I ever played. The story is a weaker ninja story, but you don't play games like this for the story. The biggest plus is the clever stealth with the use of various gadgets. The levels are really challenging and provide repetitive fun if you want to find all the collectibles and alter your gameplay - either kill and terrorize every guard in your way or be like a shadow and avoid the guards completely. For each mission you pick a costume (if you unlock them), which grants specific bonuses to each style you fight want to try out. If the screenshots and videos got your attention, don't hesitate about Mark of the Ninja, it's even better when you try it! 9/10
There are ninjas\n

Moving stealth into 2d may seem like oversimplification, but here it clarifies, turning every step into a puzzle of timing and tools. Mark of the Ninja is probably one of the best stealth games in a while because it removes the guesswork and trial and error of many stealth games. It's also very solid in that no tool or toy goes wasted, and I can't remember any device going unused. It's also a fair deal longer than I expected, and I'm looking forward to playing on a higher difficulty, something I rarely worry about these days with my game collection being what it is. Both very true to (ridiculous) ninja mythology and probably the most fun you might have as a ninja on the PC.

After all the hype, I was curious, despite generally not being a big fan of platformers (though I do enjoy stealth games).

I must say, I'm highly impressed; production values through the roof, and a poster child for the pro" side of the "Are video games Art?" argument.

If anything

reviewText: Mark of the Ninja is a ninja simulator, plain and simple. Stealth is as much a part of it as action is, and the strongest point of the game is the way it plays with the balance between the two in order to represent a variety of different ninja tropes. The stealth works so well due to how explicit the game is. The effects of light and sound are clearly marked, leaving no guess to the consequences of your actions. This allows for complex strategies without the sudden surprise of a detection. The game's finer points are explained by a companion, Orai. This keeps tutorials and backstory in the game's context while allowing the protagonist to remain silently stoic, both avoiding an assigned protagonist personality and playing towards another ninja trope. The game's weakest areas seem to be those that weren't developed simultaneously; the cartoony art style, the same one used in the studio's previous game, doesn't quite jive with Mark of the Ninja's more serious tone and the PC control scheme leaves something to be desired. Several actions are tied to single keys based on exacting and constantly changing contexts. Despite clearly marking the outcome, this makes complicated maneuvers almost impossible to execute swiftly. As far as the DLC, the only strong point of it seems to be the commentary. It does add a new ninja path and two new weapons which do add a new set of options and restrictions, but that doesn't totally change the game. Which begs the question of whether commentary is worth the extra expense.
Great for short sessions (in case you don't have time for more serious and demanding games).

MotW hits that weird stealth uncanny valley where you feel like a shadow god, but not in all the right ways. The guard AI is smart, the art direction is neat, but there's something that feels weird about accidentally jumping on top of a building and realizing that I've hit an invisible wall in a 2D game. It's not that the game is bad or that the design should be limitless, Mark of the Ninja just feels like an experience handcrafted to make me feel like a cool guy who kills a bunch of people.

Metal Gear Solid 2, on the other hand, is a game that only becomes expressive after you've decided to die a bunch of times. It's linear, but the tools Kojima gives you are entirely built for survival on harder difficulties.

I guess what I'm saying is that while Mark of the Ninja is a great game, it seems to miss out on the part of stealth games where you get killed a lot and are able to feel more powerful as you explore your options. It's good, though, and you should buy it!

Mark of the Ninja is an interesting cross of stealth and 2D platforming. You are in control of a nameless ninja protagonist that undertakes various missions, and to that end, you have an array of tools and techniques at your disposal for hiding from, distracting, and even stealth killing the various enemies you will run into along the way. While it is technically possible to engage in direct combat, it is basically never a good idea to do so, as your character severely lacks in raw durability.

Because of this, Mark of the Ninja is more of a puzzle-based platformer than a combat-based one. Many areas require some thinking and planning in order to get yourself safely through, particularly if you aim for the bonus challenges and achievements that the game is full of. Thankfully, the game provides you with many audio and visual indicators of enemy behavior, such as their sight/hearing radius, keeping the frustration aspect of the game pleasantly minimal and letting you focus your attention on the particular details of whatever area you're in.

The one main criticism I would make about Mark of the Ninja is the repetitive nature of it. While the game definitely makes efforts to keep things fresh and provide you with new challenges, you will probably find that a handful of core tools and techniques can be repeatedly used for most purposes. This isn't helped by the presentation aspects of the game; while the artstyle and music are very appropriately done, their sparse nature makes it difficult to feel like you're really experiencing new environments, and the story, while not terrible, isn't really worth remembering or mentioning.

Still, for all that, Mark of the Ninja definitely provides solid hours of engaging puzzles (if that's your thing), and if you find you want more of the gameplay, the bonus content and the DLC (which I haven't looked at) is probably worth a look.
