I thought I had played the ultimate stealth game by the time I had finished Gunpoint and I shouldn't say I have been proven wrong but I haven't been proven right either. Mark of the Ninja is a terrific stealth game in which only your creativity and some slightly rough game mechanics are the limits. You take on the role as a ninja of the Hisomu clan nad set out on a mission to avenge your fallen comrades after a raid on your clan's home.
The game offers a rich amount of tools that you can use as you progress through the various missions. Your items include a sword, darts, a grappling hook, various items used for distraction and some used for trap kills.
You can choose to kill every enemy alive or go unseen through the whole game but no matter what your moral choices are, you'll hopefully find yourself striving towards some very addictive additional goals during the playthrough.

Of course, the game isn't perfect and that should be noted. I never enjoyed the art style a lot. That is because it felt rather American, while the game revolves around japanese characters. Some of the mechanics are slightly buggy and that can be bothersome until you find your way around it. The last enemies in the game just feel rather cheap and overpowered. One annoyance is that there are some achievements that you can only unlock if you have the DLC, which feels like a cheap way to make users purchase it just to beat the game 100%.

I haven't played too much stealth games in the many year's of gaming but offhand I have to say that this is a pretty sweet deal. Those who are fans of classic side scroll games should get this one as it makes for a good break from all the usual mechanics of the platform.

The shadowy business you get into in this games is presented quite well. The art style was the first thing that got me hooked - this game is the bloodier, darker, more violent cousin of Samurai Jack. Set in a modern day metropolis, the environment makes for a good contrast to the ancient arts of the ninja. The ancient ways will be challenged by all modern means - guns, spotlights, motion sensors, and laser triggered security.

The shadowy arts never felt any simpler with the smoothness of controls - there is little room for the awkward movements and bad camera angles in this 2D platformer. Slipping in and out of the shadows is one click away! This, I think, is another good score for the game as it leaves only your good timing and judgement to deal with a present challenge.

Levels have varied goals to meet - the game can't be done perfectly by just staying hidden in the shadows forever. There are instances where your blade will get stained. (In some occasions, the goals aren't even related to being a ninja but it's all fun and challenging all the same.)

As you progress into the game, your are introduced to its very own customization system. Clearing goals allow you to buy additional stealth kills and improved ninja styles and tools.

The story - which I haven't finished, actually, isn't really that unique. Revenge and self-preservation is its very core to say the least, cloaked in shadow and with a very sharp sword.

For those who are fans of side-scrolling and stealth, this one should definitely not be missed.

I held off on getting and then playing this game for a long time (I absolutely detest Shank 2).
How wrong I was!
I fell totally in love with it. Controls are ideal, levels are designed to give you multiple options for objective completion. There are usually alternate paths to avoid or take out guards in different ways, for example. The scoring/leaderboard system encourages you to replay levels and beat your record. If you're good at the game and know what to expect in a level, you can really fly through - but each level can also take quite a long time, especially if you're looking for the secrets (and want to unlock all the goodies - different stealth moves and weapons!).

I think player progression is key in making a great game - ask yourself if you become a better player as you progress through the game. If not, then it's mostly just a time sink. If yes, then the rewards are much greater! In Mark of the Ninja, the answer is a resounding yes, a testament to how polished and well-designed the game is.

Put simply, Mark of the Ninja is one of the best interpretations of the stealth genre we've seen in years.  If you found yourself put off by the developer's earlier efforts, please do not let that keep you from giving this amazing game a go.

The stealth mechanics are brilliantly thought out and cater to a variety of playstyles, the stages are thoughtfully designed with many paths toward objectives, and there are enough optional challenges to keep you busy for quite a while.

Mark of the Ninja is just straight-up one of the best games of 2012. It's satisfying and fun to play, looks absolutely fatnastic, and has a story that requires studying the subtle nuances to fully enjoy. I'm hard-pressed to think of what more one could ask for, especially given this game's price point.
Alongside the original Thief series this is singlehandedly one of the best stealth games I've ever played.\n\nWould definitely recommend.

Mark of the Ninja is a slick and stylish stealth action platformer.

You infiltrate and assassinate your way through 12 gorgeously designed levels. The art is beautiful and the animations are slick. There is a range of environments, each with stunning vibrant parallax scrolling backgrounds offsetting the generally monochrome foreground.

You start out with a relatively simple set of moves, introducing you to how stealth works in the game; Enemies have vision cones, moving quickly makes sound which draws enemies, you can hide behind environmental objects like vases and dumpsters, slipping through vents and setting up ambushes.

The game slowly increases your equipment and move set (all of which can be customised) as you play. Each level has challenges for you to attempt, each of which unlocks a token you can spend on upgrading your gear. Complete enough of certain challenge types will unlock new costumes which include a gear restriction or boon. For example, completing 3 'Terror' challenges unlocks a gear set that makes you run without making any noise, but you lose your sword, forcing you to a fast and non-lethal playstyle.

The story is relatively simplistic, but presented in short stylized cutscenes that work well. The story has a twist with a choice at the end, but it is nothing earth-shattering and not really the focus of the experience. The joy here is in the gameplay, the smooth controls (even if playing with a keyboard and mouse) and the art.

After completion you unlock a new game plus mode, which increases the number of guards and increases the difficulty.

2D stealth game that has managed to balance the difficulty curve across nearly 12 full levels. Extremely replayable with leaderboards as well as many side objectives and collectibles hidden in the darkness of your player's surroundings.

Enjoy!

A stylized 2D take on the stealth genre. Overlooked this game for a while but really glad I picked it up. The game has a decent sized campaign with lots of challenges in every level. I found there was a lot of ways to approach every situation, either with lethal or non lethal takedowns, entry points or use of gadgets. Really felt like a true badass ninja in this game. You have the ability to terrorize your enemies and sink back into the shadows, causing them to panic and attack other guards, it's pretty great. I felt like Batman. Like I said very nicely stylized, which I expected from a Klei game. Nice art direction and animations all around, and cool tradition ninja themes mixed with more high-tech stuff. Still think I'm going to play this more to complete more challenges and play with different loadouts and ninja suits. If you're into stealth or sidescrollers I'd say pick this up!

Mark of the ninja is a simple side scroller with an insanely good Gameplay and brilliant story. In Gameplay you can choose to go stealthy and avoid enemies or go for a more direct approach with wicked assassination moves. The game has just one downside on which I can comment. It lacks innovation. Yes the game has an awesome story, fun GamePlay and you  will probably enjoy the game if you play it but it doesn’t bring anything new to the table. Made by the same developers, this greatly less brutal stealth-action inherits the flawless visual style of Shank. And raises it to the absolutely new level. What about gameplay? Nothing special, just a best stealth of the year. Dishonored? Hitman? Blah...

My first impression of this game was a quick little stealth title to hold me over for an hour or two. Little did I know that I would have eventually put in nearly 30 hours of quality gaming into this artistic masterpiece.

Right off the bat I could tell how polished and clean the graphics were. What really made the game sing were the simple lighting effects and the amazing depth of field they added. Depth of field in a 2D game! Who would've thought. Basically, whatever isn't in your character's line of sight is blurry. Simple yet added a nice touch to the game. The running, killing, climbing, etc animations were all fluid and sexy. Nice simple cinematics added to the feel of the game.

So it looks great, and sounds just as good. I love the ambiance in the game. The drums are my favorite, really sets the pace of the game. Audio is nice and smooth, nothing sounded off while playing.

The gameplay itself was something unexpected. It started off simple, and got more complex as it continued. I had no problems finishing the levels while either killing everyone or not killing anyone. Most levels had several paths and ways to handle every situation. Even more so, with the array of tools you're provided to handle missions. I honestly never came to a part of the game that frustrated me, or made me want to rage quit. With each obstacle presented, I had fun figuring out the best way to handle each situation.

Mark of the Ninja is going on my top list of favorite games. It's well worth the $15 asking price, regardless of any kind of steam sale. Crossing my fingers for a sequel.

*INITIAL IMPRESSIONS*\nI'll be the first one to admit, I don't have much of a mind for stealth games (Dishonored being the only stealth game I well and truly enjoyed), Mark of the Ninja is a hardcore stealth title. There is no actual combat, meaning if the player is spotted then you have to run, hide and accept the penalty to your final score.\nI like the concept of sticking to the shadows and utilizing the environment to move from point to point to avoid being seen, the player can climb to higher areas, hide in vents, duck behind cover or create a distraction to keep out of the sightlines of the patrolling guards. What I dislike about MotN is how the kills are managed, utilizing one of my greatest gaming pet-peeves, quick-time events. When you approach an enemy and click on them to begin your attack, the game will give you a split-second warning to slide your mouse either to the left or the right, a successful attempt will give you a silent assassination while failure to complete the event will end up making a lot of noise and attracting nearby guards. (This is especially bad if you're like me and you can never immediately figure out left from right on the spot. Don't you DARE judge me).

I don't remember the last time I was so taken by a 2D game. But by this I sure was, maybe it's even the best 2D game I ever played. The story is a weaker ninja story, but you don't play games like this for the story. The biggest plus is the clever stealth with the use of various gadgets. The levels are really challenging and provide repetitive fun if you want to find all the collectibles and alter your gameplay - either kill and terrorize every guard in your way or be like a shadow and avoid the guards completely. For each mission you pick a costume (if you unlock them), which grants specific bonuses to each style you fight want to try out. If the screenshots and videos got your attention, don't hesitate about Mark of the Ninja, it's even better when you try it! 9/10
If u have i silly willy i think u will love this game
A remarkably good stealth game.\nGood range of items and abilities with enough restriction on how many or what type you can bring to keep it interesting.

In a time when stealth segments are merely tacked onto any game, and never really expanded upon, MotN comes out and fills a stealth genre gap that greatly needed filling. Not only does it do that, it does so masterfully, with strong attention to all of the things that can make or break a stealth game.\nThe art deco inspired aesthetics fit the japanese and urban settings surprisingly well, characters animate great and special attention is given to each locale in order to accommodate the stealth based nature of the game. A very important aspect of any stealth game is the sound design, this one nails it, it has a somber, unobtrusive score and slick audio cues for situations when a silent pursuit is close to turn into an unwanted confrontation. The mechanics and items are varied and tend to bolster the options available for handling situations. You'll rarely, if ever, get bored of what's being offered.\nUmmm... Yeah, you should play this.

Great stealth game. This game has good mechanics and the variety of traps/weapons will make you play your own style: leave the  environment untouched, make key kills or mass murder the guards, is up to you.

This game is great and am really enjoying it.  It is overall very well made:  comic book-esque animation beautifully done including animated cut scenes; voice acting is very quality; controls with a Playstation (and I assume Xbox) are very good and fit perfectly with the gameplay, which also very excellent and fun (I have not tried playing with a keyboard and/or mouse).  I am also enjoying the plot so far.

The best way I can inadequetely describe the game is a wonderful side scrolling combination of Tenchu and stealth/predator aspects of the recent Batman Arkham games that is completely unique in its own way and doesn't feel derivitive of either.

My only minor quibble is that I wish there were more variation in the stealth kills, both requiring more variety in skill/button combinations to execute as well as more variety in execution moves/deaths, though I am not very far in the game and these may have already been implemented, just haven't gotten there yet.

I got this on sale, but I would have been fine if I had paid the full price (which is currently $14.99), and I highly recommend this game to anyone whom finds the above description appealing.

Disclaimer: This review contains big words and actual english. If this seems frightening or overbearing, feel free to ignore this review, and refer to the average 3-line steam review of your choice. But if you do, you're pretty much a troglodyte.

Mark of the Ninja is a 2d stealth game by Klei, the same guys who made Shank and Shank 2. The same buttery fluid animations and art direction are present in Mark of the Ninja. Quite frankly, the game looks amazing in motion. Once you get the hang of the controls and the environments, you put whatever the current-gen protagonists of Assassin's Creed are called to shame. That's inadequate, you make the free-running elements in AC look like a geriatric with a crutches by comparison.

The story, so far (I've yet to beat it), is rather straight-forward stuff. You've gotten inked by your clan's tattooist Dosan, with ink which heightens your senses and gives you a convenient array of abilities that are mainstays in video games. But the downside is that the ink burns you out, and will ultimately drive you mad. So you've taken this Mark, in order to undertake a mission to safeguard your clan's existence.
And once you've completed your task, you're going to kill yourself.

Before that though, truckloads upon truckloads of henchmen are going to get theirs.
Alternatively, they will not even know you were there.

Klei made the Shank games. Shank games are 80-ish action homages as sidescrolling beat-em-up. MotN is the AC/Batman/Splinter Cell/Tenchu/Sneak-em-up treatment of a sidescroller. You have essentially complete freedom in how you choose to undertake your missions. And by how, I mean the level of lethality and bloodshed that will befall those who made the poor career choices that culminated in ending up on the wrong side of your blade. Or those ninja traps you will unlock or buy eventually. Or, you will just quietly slip by them. Hiding in doorways, behind potted plants, crawling past them on the ceiling, grappling from lamp-post to lamp-post above their heads, sneaking in the vents below or above them. The sneaking is really good. Like REALLY good, REALLY good.

Your equipment at first consists of firecrackers for distraction, a sword for stealth killing (kills are executed like a QTE, but not nearly as annoying. You press a direction and X to cut someone up), and that's all you got at first.
Later on you get a grappling hook, spike traps which work like land mines, smoke bombs and more fun stuff to play around with.

There are challenge rooms you might encounter (they look like gongs), which mix up the regular levels by being more of platforming challenges/puzzles. They use the normal game elements to complete, which manages to both freshen up how you think about the environments and traps/hazards in the game, as well as giving you a fresh lease on how to approach situations in subsequent levels.

I know a lot of game reviews fall prey to the pitfalls of hyperbole and similes, and I've already planted my foot firmly in that territory. And I kinda detest that. But honestly, it's impossible to do it when talking about MotN.

Hell, it's just straight-up amazing.

The stealth&stalk bits are great. The array of gadgets are groovy, as is the techniques you unlock with honor points as you complete levels. Some of them are different types of stealth kills, while another lessen the sound you make while sprinting, or allow you to string up dead guard from lamp posts in order to frighten other guards senseless. You can actually terrify guards to the point of them losing it completely, where they just start shooting wildly at everything they see or imagine they see. The only downside so far, is that sometimes it's a bit wonky whether you get the bonus for hiding bodies or not, and you might have to drop them a couple of times before it registers. Or possibly that's just left in there as a reference to Metal Gear Solid games. I'm not putting it past these devs, this is obviously a labour of love.

This is definitely a high-score type of operation, and I'm gonna come back to these levels.
You're scored on stealth kills.
You're scored on sneaking past guards closely while remaining undetected, and on distracting them.
You're scored on equipment kills, on terrifying guards (and the possible resulting friendly fire), and hiding bodies.

In each level, you can find 3 scrolls which tell the story of your clan and how it came to be, and what led up to you taking on the Mark in the first place. These also give you a point of honor each, which is used to purchase upgrades inbetween missions or at banner stops within levels.

There are also 3 seals per level. Seals are the same thing as optional objectives or challenges.
These seals fall into Path of Hunter, Combat, Nightmares or Shadow.
(Names subject to making-up by me, just now, seeing as it's late and I can't be arsed to start the game to be correct.)
Completing enough of these nets you new outfits with special pros and cons. For instance, the sneaky suit silences the sound of running feet, and allows you to carry 2 distraction items in your loadout. But the tradeoff is your sword.

For anyone who enjoys 2d games with tight controls, this is a must.
For anyone who enjoys cartoon violence, this is a must.
If you've ever played a game that had a great single-player campaign, but was hamstrung by a forced multiplayer that was just put in there in order to sell the game to people who think singleplayer games are a waste of time, you need to get this in order to support the practice of making great games that don't need no multiplayer".
For anyone who played and enjoyed any of the stealth elements in any of the recent Arkham games
date: this is a must.\nFor anyone who has ever daydreamed of being a ninja
recommended:
this is a must.


...I just want slap a "MUST BUY" sticker on this.
The rest of all the games I bought this holiday sale and have yet to play might turn out to be complete ♥♥♥♥
hoursPlayed: but Mark of the Ninja more than makes up for that possibility."

reviewText: Absolutely fantastic game, definitely worth a purchase! Beautiful visuals with a nice story to boot. Gameplay is challenging and fun. If you are thinking of buying it just go ahead!

Instead of trying to make stealth realistic, the developers have focused on making stealth FUN. And they have succeeded. You will feel like a badass ninja. Brutally murdering an unsuspecting enemy and hanging his corpse from a pole to panick their mates, only to end up mercilessly murdering them too... I've had a blast with this game.

A thinking man's game that's also insanely fun to play, Mark Of The Ninja is stealth perfected on a 2D plane. There are numerous ways to approach any given situation: use darts to create distractions that help you navigate your way undetected past guards, lure enemies into traps you set, dangle above them and string them up Batman-style, hide in a vent below and pull them under or let them pass...whether you choose to go full stealth and avoid everyone or to murder all the bad guys on screen, the game rewards you, which is refreshing given that most stealth games penalize you for taking the latter route despite how much fun it is. Your enemy's field of vision is represented as a Metal Gear Solid-style cone and the audible noises you make as expanding & contracting circles - this results in the near-complete absence of a HUD, which further immerses you in the game's superb Sumi-E art design as the difficulty rises on a steady incline, never failing to challenge you in new and creative ways. Mark Of The Ninja stylishly takes its place among the best of its kind and deserves every bit of the acclaim it's garnered.

Good fun platform stealth game.

Really liked the game.
Interesting story development.
Smooth controls using controller - KB/mouse less so.

Achieved most all collectables and special goals for each level first time round.  So might be a little easy.
Levels didn't take too long - good for a short gaming session.
But worth playing if you like 2d platform games and NINJA's! (who doesn't like creeping around like a ninja?)

To start: I used to add a header to these reviews, but since it often made the review too long to submit, I've opted to leave it on my Backloggery page.\n\nGameplay: I never really was all that great at the Stealth genre, given my very guns-a-blazing kind of playstyle. Nevertheless, I usually have a lot of fun with the games. Mark of the Ninja is one of the most fun stealth games that I've played in a long time, as well as being one of the most immersive. The reason why is because of the stage design. Stages are absolute monsters that sometimes feel like a Super Metroid level than anything else. This game has a lot of exploration capabilities as well as plenty of non-linear apporaches you can take to meet objectives. There's even plenty of items to suit your playstyle. Do you wanna have fun scaring the pants off of enemies? String up bodies on grapple points. Are you a fan of the out of sight
date: out of mind" mentality of guard AI? There's a suit that allows you to have full motion silence with the tradeoff of not being able to bring a sword with you. I'm more of a fan of going undetected and (preferably) not killing anyone
recommended: as I feel that stays truest to the stealth genre as a whole. However
voteText: you could always hack your way out of a scenario.\n\nWhile I hardly did any fighting myself

reviewText: Mark of the Ninja is a wonderful stealth based game with a surprisingly well thought out story. As far as 2-D stealth platformer games go, Mark of the Ninja is definitely the king. The player must use a veriety of tools along with the environment to either kill the gaurds, or sneak past them. The player is heavily rewarded with staying out of combat, and remaining undetected which proposes a unique challange to each player. The points the player receive will also help them upgrade their arsonal and allow them to complete each level more easily; which is good, because as the game progresses the levels become increasingly difficult. If you're looking for a challenging stealth and puzzel type game, look no further.

Mark of the Ninja is one of the best stealth games that I've ever played.

The 2D layout, various execution methods, plentiful items, soundtrack, and art take this game to the top. There are different paths that you can choose throughout the game and you can pick one according to your playstyle. Whether you want to sneak around guards and be non-lethal or if you want to create the largest bloodbath the world has ever seen, the possibles for you are endless in this stealth game.

The way that vision is handled is very precise and clean. Vision tends to make or break stealth games but this one does it incredibly well.

The achievements aren't too hard to get either if you're a hunter.

Great game that proves that 2D is not dead and is an overall better choice for stealth and platforming. Enjoyable from beginning to end, quite diverse in the approaches to a level, tight controls (with a X360 controller). Must buy!

I go back to this game every so often and play through it again.  It's satisfying and pretty and I honestly wish it was much much bigger and longer and had a 3D version.   Good stealth games are hard to find and this one always leaves me wanting more.
Lots of puzzle fun with great animation. Much more engrossing than I expected and it's been hours of fun so far.
I just threw some maneating bugs at some poor guard, watching his buddies freak the f*ck out while he was eaten alive, and then they shot each other.\nI'm high on ninja fantasies. Join me
The true ninja is here.

Mark of the Ninja makes being a ninja a pretty badass thing. No matter how you want to play through this game, there are rewarding and satisfying ways to go about your business as a shadow, a samurai, a hidden blade, and/or a sadist, while a top ninja embraces all four and knows when to employ them.

Unbelievable for what you pay for it. Customize your loadout and walk through environment puzzles, all the while being either super sneaky or hack-and-slashy. I  loved it so much I played through the regular game twice - once without a sword. I'll probably end up getting the DLC.

While some parts end up frustrating, the game as a whole keeps things at a great pace and does a great job of moving the player forward.
Take care with this game, the power to consume time is underrated.

It also rewards not only a combat oriented approach, but pacific runs too. Get it!

reviewText: This is one of the best ninja games ever.

Certainly one of the best game's I've played in this genre and theme. You really feel like a ninja, the smooth controls and intriguing levels make it an allover enjoyable experience. Although the campaign is slightly short (with no multiplayer) I personally still got more hours of enjoyable gameplay then I get from most big AAA releases. Certainly worth a try even if you're on the edge, if it's your kinda genre it's a must-buy.

This is one of the most innovative games I have ever played. Like the reviews say, it is a testament to stealth based games. I felt more like an assassin here than in Assassin's Creed II. I am not bashing Assassin's Creed at all, I love it, but it doesn't pull off stealth based platforming like Mark of the Ninja. This game has amazing replayability, with different items and costumes to fit different playstyles. For instance, in every level you can bypass without killing anyone, using the suit of darkness. The items in this game allow the entire game to be played in different and more challenging ways. I highly suggest it if you are into good humored, amazing platforming and really feeling like a ninja.

This game is all about ninjas. REAL NINJAS.  This game is awesome. My name is Sam and I can't stop thinking about ninjas. These guys are cool; and by cool, I mean totally sweet.

A great chemistry between traditionally different elements and a big love letter to those who enjoy fluid side-scrollers and the stealth genre.

The graphics are simple yet effective. Animations are smooth, non-redundant and tastefully exaggerated.

Controls are incredibly compact, which will certainly help you stay in function in every single move. This is absolutely important in an action-stealth game.

Gameplay in Mark of the Ninja is highly innovative, and also very brutal. You as a ninja are given a wide variety of equipment, tools and courses of actions to proceed and complete your missions. However, make one wrong move, and you may consider yourself finished, as you are a Ninja, not a Rambo. The shadow is your friend, not the fists.

Overall, Mark of the Ninja is an absolute gem of the 2D side-scroller and stealth genre. If you are a big fan of either of those, or both, then this game is definitely a must-have.

reviewText:
Thoroughly reccomend this game. Storyline is interesting enough to keep you indulged in the game and progress to find out what happens next, and pretty well written for an indie game.

Worth noting that the gameplay does start off a little slow and may seem a little less promising -- it gets better as you play.

Worth picking up if you're into assassin-stealth like genre of games (eg. Hitman, Assassin's Creed, etc)

Note: Much more enjoyable with a controller.

Best stealth game I've ever played. Awesome art style, exciting, fun, tense. Gameplay just feels so great. Lots of replay value if you're into collectibles and 100% completion. Just an incredibly good game.

Fantastic 2D stealth platformer.  The gameplay mechanics are original and intuitive.  The story seemed bland and unoriginal at first but I was pleasantly surprised at how it turned around near the middle and evolved into a moral dilemma for which either side could be argued.

The game is a good length too; I was able to beat the main story in about 9 hours.  There's a great amount of replayability thanks to each level's goals, the extra unlockables, and the more difficult story mode replay which is unlocked after beating the main story.  I was able to manage with KB+M controls but I preferred using a controller (as is usually the case with me).

Highly recommended, even at full price.

This game is extremely underrated. I'd say it actually stands up there with Thief and Deus Ex in terms of stealth. If you like stealth, this game is a way better(and cheaper) investment than Dishonored. Give these guys your money.

Beautiful Art Style. Amazingly Written Story. Original Combat System.

Mark of the ninja is a 2D stealth platformer created by Shank creators, Klei Entertainment. To the game's credit the story is more complex than it makes out to be, which leaves the player thinking about their decisions by end of the game. The music does a great job at giving the sense of tension in stealth games.

The gameplay is trully where this game shines. As a ninja you have a vast amount of gadgets available to deal with gaurds such as spike traps, bug swarm, smoke bomb etc. The levels are quite large, generally offering more than one route to reach an objective. Frontal assaults are inefficient at taking out gaurds as it takes alot of hits to knock them down for kill, whille you can die in a few shots. Unlike other stealth games, you can easily see whether your out of site due the the character model changing from coloured (visible) to black (invisible),which means that deaths are hardly the game's fault but rather the player's. There are also alot of places to hide in including rooms, garbage bins and ventilation shafts. The open ended levels and the variety of gadgets allow the player to play their own way (you can even win some levels without killing anyone if your good).

Mark of the Ninja is an excellent game for players who love stealth games with some platforming involved.
Awesome game!

Simple yet addicting game, I game belongs to the new generation of platformers, that although simple in design and Game Play are reach on detail and specially storyline, this is a game definitely worth giving a try, if you want to try something old school with a new twist.
Veritable stealth-action Castleroid. Get.

I like it, great mechanic, eye-pleasing art style which somehow reminds me of Samurai Jack, and one thing that impressed me the most is you can maximise all of the potentials of your ability, both combat or non-combat without ever worrying on how will they affect the ending. You can either stealthily murder everyone on your path, brutalize and terrorize your foes with no regards for stealth, or even don't let anyone know you were crawling right through them. Definitely recommending this game to every stealth game fan out there.

A sidescrolling stealth game that manages to make it work, Mark of the Ninja has room for creativity and strategy in approaching objectives rarely found in sidescrollers, frequently giving the player even more meaningful tactical choices than its 3D counterparts. A competent game all around.

First of all, lemme just say this - Playing this game should be a mandatory part of training for any game devs planning a stealth game. This is how it should be done!\nNow on with the review -  Don't be fooled by the 2D graphic style…its every bit as complex and enthralling as any AAA stealth game out there, in fact much more. Amazing story, fantastic stealth mechanics and out of this wold gameplay. What more do you want? Do yourself a favour and pick this one up immediately even if you have a passing interest in stealth games and/or want to feel like a true Ninja assassin!

Mark of the Ninja is basically the stealth elements of Arkham Asylum wrapped in a 2D sidescroller with kimpossiblesque graphics and a modern popcultural ninja setting. I would unconditionally recommend this game to anyone, who is at least remotely fond of the genre.

If you are *at all* interested in stealth as a gameplay mechanic, pick this game up! The core action & platforming are slick, the visuals are spot on, and they do a good job of setting up secondary objectives if you feel like exploring for One Millions Bonus.

Mark of the ninja is hands down one of the best platformers out there. It spoke a lot and I am reviewing it after playing it for quite a while. Nowadays, Platformers are the most approachable genres for developers, the way I see it and it is hard to tell which is more innovative and it is harder for the developers to innovate because there are so many ideas out there already. Mark of the ninja broke that boundary and provided us with a simple concept and great writing. The story was engaging to say the least and I cant imagine someone nowadays missing out on it. Get it and you will have a great time.

Easily one of the best Stealth games out there. Mark of the Ninja is one of the best games to come out in 2012. As a stealth game it's really well done, the idea that you're a ninja and not a samurai is a brilliant emphasis on the play style this game presents. As a Ninja your mission is to avenge your clan and take out the bad guys. Pretty simple in the story department. Gameplay is 2D and all the information you need to know is there, how much sound you make is given off by rings broadcasted from the last position you made noise, if enemies are with the radius of these rings then they'll investigate. The greatest thing is enemies suffer from fear, as you do horrible things to the unlucky schmucks they'll start panicking and this can go either way as they shoot their buddies or hit you in the process. Combat is pretty non-existent in this game. You can stun enemies, but you'll most likely be out-numbered and killed in that pursuit. Instead your attacks come in the form of gadgets, like traps. As long as an enemy cannot see you, you can kill in up-close stealth take-down form! The last point I want to make is masks. Masks alter the game in subtle ways that change how you approach sandboxes for example there is a mask that lets you take more Offensive gadgets or there is a mask that makes your enemies panic if they see corpses of their buddies anywhere (not just hanging from lamp-posts). The masks are all unlockable and this ties in with the game's replayability. The game is already highly replayable but the masks add different flavours of fun, and that's something the game is, amazing fun!

This game is easy enough to start playing, that many will find it entertaining.

The game is simple but very fun to play.
You can choose two paths while playing each level. Either stealth or bloodbath/terror.
Terrorizing  guards is one of the most intresting elements in this game. Sometimes its enough killing one guard, and hang the body in the ceeling. Making several other guards go nuts and start fire wild in random directions. Also killing other guards.
The DLC is an intresting twist that also unlocks some more equipment for the main stoy. Its not that expensive and also get my thumb up. I recommend that if you have managed to clear the 5 first levels, buy the DLC for some more equipment. Some of it is quite helpful at that stage.

reviewText: Mark of the Ninja does something I love. It allows mulitple ways for you to play it, and then rewards how you play it with more options within that style. It is such a slick and artful stealth platformer, with superbly tight controls and creative challenges. All approaches to any level are excecuted engagingly and players can flow between them effortlessly. Like a ninja. Fantastic.
I recommend it to buy it on sale.\nGreat game and story!\n8,5/10
